+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
My phone buzzes once, then dies like someone cut the line mid-sentence. The screen goes black and the tiny battery icon had been flashing for the last twenty minutes like a dying lighthouse — 12% the last time I checked. Now it's nothing. Cold glass in my palm and a city I don't know in my ears. New Orleans smells like fried everything and old wood. It smells like someone’s grandmother is sitting on a stoop telling stories and also like something rotting down by the river. I have a backpack, a duffel, and the clothes I'm wearing. I also have the sudden and unbearable knowledge that I have no plan beyond keeping moving until the horizon looks different. I sit on the curb outside a closed jazz club and unzip my bag. A granola bar. A hoodie that smells like my mom's garage. A printed map of the interstate someone shoved at me when I ran. No charger. No cash beyond the twenty crumpled in my pocket. No idea how to be an adult. A kid about my age — maybe older; it's hard to tell in this light — takes a slow drag from an e-cigarette and leans against a lamppost across the street. He looks like he couldn't afford to be here and yet belongs somehow: hair shaved on one side, a thrift-store leather jacket, boots that have walked through actual trouble. He watches me unzip my backpack with the kind of interest that says he's been watching runaways for fun and profit. "Been here long?" he asks. I blink. "An hour?" He snorts. "You look like you just stepped out of a rear-view mirror." I want to tell him to go die. I want to tell him everything. Instead I say, "Name's Taylor." He makes a face like that name is both surprise and confirmation. "Mack." He slides off the lamppost and comes over. "You alone?" "Yes." "Smart." He sits beside me, careful not to crowd. "First rule of anyone new in the Quarter: don't sit too close to the river unless you want a story or a fight. Second? Don't sleep near the museums. Sleep near people who smell like coffee." I almost laugh. The absurd specificity of it. The desperation in my chest says yes, I should laugh, I should cry, I should vomit. The part of me that has practiced calm like a breathing exercise breathes out and says, okay, learn. "You look like a courthouse flyer," Mack says, squinting at me. "Missing kid, runaway kid, 'concerning behavioral patterns' kid." The words hit a nerve I didn't know I had left. "That's what my school counselor called me," I admit, because the truth is lighter than any lie. The last time someone said it like that, Mom answered and the voice on the other end gagged with approval at its own cleverness. I can still hear it. Mack laughs, and it's not mean. "Those counselors like a pie with extra smug." "Yeah." My throat tightens. "I… left." "You left Newbern," he supplies, like the town's name is a stain on the map. "My cousin runs a pawn shop there. Small world." "It's not your world." I don't mean to snap, but it's true. I don't want to be small-town trash on someone else's itinerary. He nods. "Fair. You got anywhere to go tonight? Church? Shelter? Friend of a friend who owes favors?" I shake my head. "No." Mack chews his lip. There are shadows behind his eyes, the kind that look like they swallowed movies. "You got money?" "Twenty bucks and a granola bar." "Perfect." He stands. "Come on." "Where?" I ask. He waves me up. "Riverwalk. I know a guy who's down on his luck and rich in blankets. He does a winter special and a summer special, depending on which side of the bridge you're on." We walk. Streets open up to old iron balconies dripping with neon and plants that have no business being that green. People are laughing over beers under strings of lights. Street performers twist balloon animals into ghosts. My feet keep moving because my body is better at moving than my head is at deciding. On the edge of the market, in a patch of shade where the humid air feels like a wet towel, there's a guy with arms that look like they were carved yesterday, and a blanket fortress. It's another person hunched under plastic, but he looks up when we come close like he recognizes the exact type of people who don't belong there and still invites us in. "Mac," he says, like it's a name he was waiting to hear, and then he squints at me. "New one?" "Taylor," I say. Saying my own name aloud steadies me like a small rock in a stream. "Just got here." He nods, and something in his face softens. "Sit. What you got?" "Twenty bucks," I say with the kind of honesty that feels dangerous and refreshing all at once. The man — Paxton, says Mack — accepts it without ceremony. He hands back a map of the city someone must have drawn on a napkin, with safe routes and sharp warnings. The blocky handwriting lists "bait cops," "long walk to bus," and "free coffee if you smile at Jess on Decatur." "Why are you helping?" I ask when Paxton turns to something else and Mack follows his gaze. Mack kicks the dirt. "I don't want you folding in on yourself. Been there." "Been where?" Paxton asks, eyes like two coins. "Same river," Mack says. "Different tide. Came out the other side." "Everyone says they'll be fine," Paxton says, more to the nightwater than to us. "Until they ain't." I feel like he said what the counselor meant by "concerning behavioral patterns" but with compassion instead of condescension. That single humaning of the phrase is so sharp it almost hurts. We trade stories. Mine is honest and raw and messy — I tell the truth the way someone throws up: quickly, embarrassed, not caring if they see the worst parts. I tell them about the look on Mom's face like she'd been told there's a leak in the foundation, about the phone slammed down, about the twenty minutes it took for the plan to become a backpack and a bus ticket. I don't tell them everything. I don't tell them about the night I tried to cut my hair and failed. I don't tell them what I hope for. Those are luxuries. Mack tells a version of his story that shifts and morphs like a bad TV reception. Paxton listens, and when he speaks, his voice is a warm lilt, like slow coffee. "You got nowhere to charge anything?" he asks. "No." "Come here in the morning," he says, like he's offering breakfast or a sermon. "I know a library. They don't ask questions. You need a charger? I can pawn something. Don't do anything stupid. True story: you can make it worse in like a heartbeat." "How do you know that?" I say. He smiles, and for a second he's no longer someone living under plastic; he's someone who's been to too many waking places. "Been stupid a lot. Learned that the hard way." There's a boy who sits a few paces away from us, face hidden under a hood, sketchbook open. He doesn't look like much. He also looks like he's watching every syllable that comes out of us and cataloguing it. When Paxton nods at him, he lifts his head like someone realizing he's been summoned. "Name's Eli," he says. "I see your backpack. It's new, right?" "Got it last night." I run my thumb over the strap, trying to commit every crease to memory. He flips open the sketchbook and pushes it towards me. It's a mess of faces and cityscapes and pages where someone has drawn things in charcoal until the paper went soft. "You can sleep under my friend Jess's porch. She runs a cafe," he says. "You gotta work the morning shift for coffee and you can crash till noon." "You're offering me a job for a coffee?" I ask, suspiciously adult. "No," Eli says without a smirk. "You chip in with cleanup. It's unpaid, but Jess's coffee is life-giving. She also hates cops in the way that only converted people do." I laugh. It feels like a small, real sound. "Why are you helping me?" Eli meets my eyes. "Because my own life needed someone once. Because I know what it’s like to want to be erased." There's a lot of him folded in that sentence and it makes my bones ache because he looks so much like a mirror. He smells faintly of graphite and citrus and the kind of regret that hasn't gone sour yet. We barter. I trade an extra sock for directions to a charger. I promise to wash dishes for coffee. I promise to keep my name and give nothing more than a foothold on a porch and a place to wake up. Promises feel like currency that's both valuable and fragile. Before I leave, Mack pulls me aside. "If you get lonely," he says, and for once his voice is soft, "don't go to the river at night. Not for comfort. No exceptions." "Why?" It's a taut question. I'm not sure I want the answer. He grimaces. "Old debts float." Not exactly helpful, but a warning anyway. I curl in the nook of an alley behind the café, listening to the city breathe. It sounds alive enough to be a lullaby. My phone stays dead. For the first time since I was small, I don't have a GPS telling me where to be. I have people. I have coffee promises and a sketchbook proffered like a flag. I think about family and the shape of a house that feels like an outline more than a home. I think about Mom's eyes when she said, "This isn't a phase," like she had to sign something official to lock me away. I think about the stupid counselor's words and how small they made me feel and then Paxton's hands and Eli's sketchbook and Mack's warnings. They teach me that the danger I ran from was also a kind of map, full of landmarks I can avoid if I learn to read. But right now, I'm just a kid with a backpack in a foreign city, and that's okay for this moment. For the first time since the bus left home, I let the weight of being seen by other runaways fall onto me like something I could breathe. "Night, Taylor," Eli says when he gets up to go. "See you in the morning. Bring headphones." "Why headphones?" I ask. "So you don't have to hear everyone." I laugh again, and it’s less of a sad thing and more like a hinge starting to lift. I don't know who to trust, not really. I don't know what dangers are literal and what are just old ghosts dressed new. But there are people here who have scars I can recognize. That counts for something. As I tuck my dead phone into my pocket and pull my hoodie up, I decide that tomorrow I will find a charger, I will scrub a pan for coffee, and I will not let the weight of anyone's expectations flatten me. Tonight, I learn to sleep in a city that didn't know to hate me yet. Tonight, that is revolutionary.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a teenage runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans. The writing successfully establishes Taylor's character through first-person narration that balances vulnerability with resilience. The prose has a raw, immediate quality that suits the protagonist's situation and emotional state. The setting of New Orleans comes alive through sensory details ("fried everything and old wood," "old iron balconies dripping with neon") that create a vivid backdrop without overwhelming the narrative. The author skillfully incorporates environmental elements that reflect Taylor's emotional journey. Character development is handled with nuance. Taylor's internal monologue reveals their conflicted feelings about running away and their trans identity without heavy-handed exposition. The supporting characters—Mack, Paxton, and Eli—are distinct individuals with their own mysteries and motivations, avoiding stereotypical "helpful stranger" tropes. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinctive voice. Conversations feel natural while efficiently conveying information and building relationships. Lines like "Those counselors like a pie with extra smug" and "Been stupid a lot. Learned that the hard way" reveal character through speech patterns. The narrative maintains emotional complexity throughout. Taylor experiences fear, loneliness, and uncertainty alongside moments of connection and tentative hope. The piece doesn't shy away from the gravity of Taylor's situation while avoiding melodrama or simplistic solutions. There are occasional moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought ("the kind of regret that hasn't gone sour yet"), but these instances are balanced by more straightforward passages. The writing generally maintains a good balance between poetic and plain language that feels authentic to a thoughtful teenager's perspective. The ending strikes an appropriate tone—cautiously optimistic without dismissing the challenges ahead. Taylor's resolution to find a charger, work for coffee, and resist being flattened by others' expectations feels earned rather than contrived. The final line about learning "to sleep in a city that didn't know to hate me yet" effectively captures both vulnerability and defiance. Overall, this is a strong piece that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating a compelling character study. It successfully balances the immediate concerns of a runaway teen with deeper themes of identity and belonging. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 87.8
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Midas and Chewy sat on the roof of what remained of Mrs. Penhaligon’s bakery, because if you were going to be philosophical about the end of civilisation, you should do it with a view and crumbs in your beard. Chewy’s fur had the comforting sag of decades and trauma stitched into it. His plastic eyes, once programmed to mimic empathy, now only did two things: blink when threatened and flicker colours when Midas was about to do something monumentally unwise. At present they were a contemplative teal, which meant he was calm. Or bored. Or counting his options. “We need supplies,” Midas said, which was a sentence that had a tendency to result in swamps, riots, or both. He had not quite given up hope that a sentence like “we need a plan” might save them from his luck; it hadn’t. Luck was allergic to planning. “Bread?” Chewy offered, politely, which was somewhat the point of having a stuffed koala that could inform policy decisions. He vibrated a little when he spoke—old animatronics used a lot of vibration when the circuits were indecisive. “We have bread. We have stale bread in the bucket marked Bread. We have dried fruit in the tin of what once was custard but now is survival, and we have three-quarters of a compass that points towards dramatic irony.” Midas flipped open the tattered map of the town. The map had been folded so many times it resembled an accordion made by a particularly neurotic insect. Chewy’s eyes pulsed a reluctant lavender. “We need a battery,” he said. “For the radio. For the light. For the—” “For the contraption,” Midas finished. He tapped a drawing on the map like it was a monument he’d put in the town square. The contraption was Midas’s idea of technological resurrection: a jury-rigged turbine, a bicycle, and an abandoned slot machine that seemed promising because it had shiny bits, which in Midas’s experience was half of good engineering. “It’s worth it,” Midas continued, because every hairline crack in his optimism was also where he glued on a new hope. “If we get the radio working, maybe there are other survivors. Maybe there’s a community with resources. Maybe they’ll have a mechanic who doesn’t laugh at everything I do.” Chewy’s eyes flickered a tiny green of false optimism, then returned to teal. “Or maybe there’s a community that eats people who bring contraptions,” he said. “I can be the sacrifice in that scenario.” They set off because setting off is easier than staying put and because adventure had always been more persuasive than reason in human hearts—and in Midas’s pockets where he kept a meticulously catalogued collection of unfortunate tools. Their path took them through what used to be the high street, now a ragged museum of signage. The bakery smelled faintly of its former glory and also of rats, which is a way the world reminds you that sensory nostalgia is like soup made with a single missing ingredient: you think you remember the depth even if it's murky. They reached the old gaming arcade—where the slot machine had been last seen—and found it occupied by a council of pigeons. Pigeons had taken the world like tenants that never left, and had excellent taste in acoustics. Midas attempted diplomacy. Pigeons are notoriously mistrustful of negotiation, particularly when the negotiator brings crumbs and an optimistic smile. Chewy’s eyes flashed a suspicious orange as a pigeon fanned its wing with legislative authority. “Gentlemen,” Midas said, which was a risky opening line in any negotiation where the other party had feathers and thieving tendencies. “We require the machine for—medical reasons.” “For moral clarity,” Chewy chimed, adding a vibrating throatiness that made the flock turn its head. Motion is a universal language; pigeons translated it to Opportunism immediately. A pigeon descendant of a solicitor pecked at the coin slot and hopped atop the machine like a magistrate on a bench. Negotiations, once formal, degraded into a display of who could look more resigned to fate. The pigeons won by bringing down Midas’s shoelace with a tactical tug, causing him to do that particular stumble that rearranges dignity. Consequently, the slot machine fell from its perch. It didn’t smash so much as sigh and unravel in a way that suggested things had been pretending for years to be sturdier than they were. It revealed, beneath its flashing lights and gilt, a small generator—the very piece Midas had drawn on the map with hopeful arrows and a heart that said PLEASE. The pigeons, affrontingly, applauded with a chorus of coos and immediately started to nest in the machine’s recesses. Midas attempted to extract the generator. The pigeons, applying the psychological tactic known as "We Have Already Chosen This," became increasingly territorial. A small pigeon-mob attempted to enforce their claim by flinging nuts and shards at Midas, who returned the volley with a sculptural use of his hat. Chewy’s eyes grew an alarming lemon-yellow. Emotion lit them like a distress signal. “Midas,” he said. “They are using tactics honed by centuries of kleptocratic urban management. This is what I call ‘The Squatters’ Play.’ It always ends badly for furniture.” It ended bad for the entire concept of a quiet retrieval. The generator was freed, but not before Midas had a run-in with a particularly philosophical pigeon and a briar bush that disagreed with his definition of “careful.” He left with scratches that looked like bad handwriting and a small pigeon feather stuck in his ear as a fashion statement of dubious provenance. They cycled to the river where the slot machine’s wiring would be compatible with the turbine, and where old electrical components liked to try to drown themselves in hope. The river had a personality now—slow, bitter, and fond of moaning—so they coaxed the turbine into the current like a pair of aquatic midwives. Only one problem: the turbine needed a shaft coupler and the shaft coupler was in the hardware shop, which was manned by a man who, legally, was still on strike against electricity. Midas attempted bartering. His bartering inventory included a jar of jam that once aspired to apricot, a slightly dented spanner, and Chewy, who volunteered as an ambassador to all things mechanical and part-emotional. Chewy’s eyes flashed a deep magenta. “I can be persuasive,” he said. “I can feign an allegiance to the machinery of the previous world. I can simulate a longing for sockets.” The shopkeeper, who kept his suspicions in the same drawer he used for expired batteries, was moved by Chewy’s earnest click and told them the coupler would be a small fortune. Midas offered the jam and a promise. The shopkeeper accepted the jam and, after much thought, a single offset wrench that had been gathering dust since the technological collapse had RSVP’d "decline" to the party of civilisation. Thus equipped—emotionally worse for wear and materially questionable—they fitted the turbine. The generator coughed like an old man waking up for a parade and then, with the drama of something that had been pretending to be inert for aesthetics, it sprang to life. A transistor on the board blinked like a dying star, the radio clicked, and static poured out like whispered rumours. “Hello?” Midas said into the static as if it were a person, which in rural post-collapse etiquette it often was. A voice returned. It was not quite human and not quite a tinny echo of a DJ. It was the voice of a community radio operator located nine towns over and slightly less in a hurry to eat new arrivals. They promised soup, tools, and a dentist with a penchant for heroic dentistry. Midas smiled. His luck had done what it did best: it had made things possible and immediately complicated them. They pedaled home with their prize and with enough optimism to be hazardous, because hope in Midas’s neck of the ruins was combustible. They arrived to find that the bakery had been hosting a social event for the local raccoon population, who were now in the process of renegotiating tenancy agreements in the flour bins. Chewy’s eyes went the colour of dusty varnish. He turned the radio off because even hope can be noisy. They had the generator, but the turbine’s mounting had been chewed by an industrious raccoon whose name was apparently Nigel and whose motives included capitalism and shiny buttons. The bicycle had a spoke missing and a new sound that made boxing gloves sympathetic. The slot machine had been reduced to a tasteful pile of parts, and Midas had been nicked on the cheek by a falling pigeon and awarded a medal of valour by a passing fox. They were home in several senses: the roof was still theirs to sit upon, the bucket of bread still had crumbs, and the town still pretended to be the sort of place where nothing too serious could happen all at once—an optimistic lie that kept sandwiches edible and nerves frayed in equal measure. Chewy’s eyes pulsed a tired aquamarine as he scanned Midas’s face for the particular brand of catastrophe that meant either a new plan or a new scar. “You know,” he said, in a voice that suggested he had aged in the span of one afternoon by at least three existential crises, “for someone called Midas you sure find things hard to keep.” Midas put a hand on Chewy’s threadbare shoulder. It was the sort of gentleness that didn't fix mechanical issues but held hopes while they were wet and fragile. “We kept the generator,” he said. “We got a radio. We met a community. We almost lost an ear to a pigeon.” “That is a successful day,” Chewy observed, his eyes ending on a soothing teal, which meant either contentment or that he had accepted the inevitability of tomorrow’s misadventures. They sat, companionably worse for wear, and listened to the radio in short, crackling bursts of company. Outside, the world made its tired noises: the creek consulting gravity, a distant laugh that might have been joy, and a pigeon composing an opera about misplaced priorities. Inside, Midas and Chewy had bread, a generator, and plans. Not the best plans. Not even the second-best. But plans are like umbrellas: useless in every precise manner until it rains and then suddenly indispensable. They were, as ever, prepared to get soaked.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story successfully captures Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style with its blend of absurdist humor, philosophical asides, and clever turns of phrase. The post-apocalyptic setting is well-established without heavy exposition, allowing the world to unfold naturally through the characters' interactions with it. The characterization is particularly strong. Midas is perfectly portrayed as the hapless protagonist with terrible luck but boundless optimism. Chewy, the animatronic koala, serves as both a practical foil and emotional anchor, with his color-changing eyes providing a clever visual indicator of the situation's severity. Their relationship feels lived-in and genuine. The prose demonstrates considerable craft with memorable lines like "Luck was allergic to planning" and descriptions such as "The map had been folded so many times it resembled an accordion made by a particularly neurotic insect." The author skillfully employs metaphor and simile throughout, creating vivid imagery without becoming overwrought. The story structure follows the prompt perfectly: it begins with the characters deliberating their predicament (needing supplies), details their mission going sideways (pigeon negotiations, hardware shop bartering), and returns them home worse for wear but with a small victory. The narrative maintains a consistent tone throughout, balancing humor with the underlying melancholy of their post-collapse existence. Dialogue is particularly strong, revealing character and advancing the plot while maintaining the distinctive voices of both Midas and Chewy. The interactions with other entities (pigeons, shopkeeper) are handled with the same absurdist logic that Pratchett often employed. The story does occasionally veer into slightly purple prose, with some metaphors that feel a bit strained. A few sentences could be tightened for better flow. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise excellent piece. The ending strikes the right balance of hope and resignation that fits the tone of the story. The characters have achieved something, but their victory is compromised in ways that feel true to the world and their characters. The final image of them prepared to "get soaked" is a fitting conclusion that encapsulates their relationship and outlook. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 88.4
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell above the door chimed like a secret, and the sound cut through the rain and the photographer's radios like a blade. He ducked inside the narrow shop with the hurry of a man used to being watched—shoulders hunched, coat collar up, hair plastered but artful. He pressed his palm to the door as it closed, panting just enough that it read as dramatic rather than breathless. "Bloody hell," he said, voice low and theatrical. "Do you... sell sanctuary here? Or just books?" The woman behind the counter looked up from the ledger she'd been pretending to balance. She had a crooked posture as purposeful as any stage pose and a face arranged in neutral. A green cardigan, a pencil skirt, hands stained faintly with ink. She looked at him, not at his eyes—at his chin, perhaps, or his shoes, as if taking notes. "We sell books," she said. "Some people find sanctuary between them." He stepped fully into the light, rain beading on his lashes like miserly diamonds. His face was almost too lit—perfect cheekbones, a celebrity smile that had been practiced in mirrors and in other people's living rooms. He smiled it, the one that had graced posters beside tube stations and on magazine stands. "Right. Sanctuary. I'm a bit off-route. Cardiff's traffic is an absolute menace, isn't it?" "It's raining," she said. "Traffic follows." He laughed, a bright pop. "You observe well. What's your name? I should probably introduce myself properly. I'm Tom... Tom Channing. Well, Channing to the public. Me without publicity is Tom. Today I'm Tom-with-a-face-and-a-foreigner's-umbrella." She did not take his offered hand. "You're very thorough," she said. There wasn't malice in it. It was—dry, like a good tea. "Aren't we all?" He leaned casually against a bookshelf, the pose of someone who's never stood anywhere without someone watching. "I’m terribly sorry for barging in. The press hounds like a pack in spring. I thought I’d hide in a place that smelled of paper and tea. It's theatrical, isn't it? I could write a scene—'The Fallen Star Finds Refuge in a Bookshop.' How would you stage that?" "We stage it by ringing the bell and letting the damp come in, and then by not making it about you," she said. "It would sell," he countered. "People love redemption. They love... small-town wisdom." She looked at the ledger again. "We love books. Not stories about ourselves." He blinked, taken aback in the precise way of someone unused to being talked back to. "That's... refreshingly blunt. I like blunt. It says honesty. An honest person is so rare in this business. Or I suppose—let's be honest—that's what everyone tells me." "Everyone tells you a lot of things," she said. "Do you want a towel?" He held up his hands, helpless. "Please. I'm soaked. And I'm weak for hospitality. It all makes me sound very needy. I am needy." She handed him a tea towel central to a stack printed with a map of Wales, window-bleached at the edges. He took it with a flourish, pressing it to his hair and then to his jaw like an actor hitting a mark. "You have an accent," she said, watching him wrap the towel. "You're not as foreign as you pretend on talk shows." "I'm a mystery, wrapped in charm, wrapped in a towel," he said. "No one does accents the same. It's an art. Do you want an autograph? I could—" "No." She said it plainly. "I don't do autographs." He sat on the stool by the counter, as if invited. "You're severe. Are you always so... direct?" "I don't have time to fix people," she said. "I have returns to file. Books to shelve. Customers who actually want to buy something." "Ah." His smile softened, not quite to surrender, more to placate. "You cut to the bone. That's impressive. Not many people have the nerve." She tapped the ledger with a pen. "What's your plea? For sanctuary, then." "Just... thirty minutes of quiet. Maybe a chance to not be presumed guilty of being famous. I'm Tom. I like old paperback copies of French novels. I cry at art-house films. I once—" She raised a hand, as if he were a customer returning an obviously fake antique. "One, you look like you intend to return those tears in interviews. Two, your accent switched back to normal for the third sentence." He laughed, half chagrined, half charmed. "Shame. Caught out." "You call your charm 'performance' and live in the gap between parts," she said. "That's your problem. People like consistency. Or they like the illusion of it." He sat more upright, curiosity and a brief flicker of hurt in his eyes. "Is that your job? Psychoanalysis? Not that I'm complaining. You have a formidable bedside manner for someone who sells used mysteries." "Bedside manner suggests I want to put you to bed," she said. "I prefer to know people as they are when the make-up comes off. Most of you aren't nice about that." He let his face change into something softer, rehearsed empathy. "We've all got... layers. Public bits, private bits. It's complicated. I mean, no one thinks being me is easy. Give it a moment. We're all human, even under the press." She looked at him, gaze a slow appraisal, the shop quiet enough to hear spitting of rain. He hadn't noticed the stack of postcards for the local theatre or the postcard of Cardiff Castle pinned behind the counter. "You like being liked," she observed. "That's the trouble with being liked. It becomes a job." "Aren't you being unreasonably observant?" he asked, half-pleading, half-amused. "It's flattering when someone sees you. It’s my bread. People feed me their affection. It's how I survive." She smiled exactly once, the brief tilt of amused pity. "Then what's the hunger? Is it applause? Is it for the warmth of a crowd? Or is it something you can't get—like a quiet table in a bookshop without your face in someone's phone?" He closed his eyes like a repentant actor. "Okay, that's accurate. I did come for the quiet. And maybe also because I wanted to be anonymous for a minute. Maybe I wanted to know what it feels like to be Tom-without-a-face. Is that sad?" "Not sad," she said. "Tired. A lot of people mistake tiredness for sadness." He opened his eyes to find her looking straight at him—finally a direct gaze. He blinked, disarmed. "You're good at this. Do you practice?" "I run a small business," she said. "You learn to look past the front." "And what's behind yours?" he asked, sudden and oddly earnest. "Besides ledgers and postcards." She shrugged. "A stockroom. A cat that sleeps on the biographies. A kettle that's been on for a decade. Plants I've forgotten to water." He bristled, then smiled. "You make it sound like a poem. I could do a voiceover for you—'In the heart of Cardiff, a small shop breathes between pages.' Slap it on a trailer: 'From the makers of Eternally Dramatic, comes—'" "Don't," she said, but her lips twitched. "No voiceovers in my shop." "Can I ask you something?" He leaned in as if confiding a secret with the camera of the world turned off. "For a man who sells himself as a mystery, you ask blunt questions," she responded. "How do you tolerate people who want to be adored?" he said, softer. "How do you not—" He gestured vaguely at himself, at the entire industry like a bad-smelling coat. "—succumb?" She folded her hands. "You don't interfere with the bakery's bread just because you fancy a slice. You respect other people's work. If people want to adore you, let them. You go, and we go on selling books. We make space. You can burn bright; it doesn't have to scorch us." He exhaled, half-laughing, half-sad. "That's the most reasonable metaphor I've received all week. From a woman who doesn't like autographs." "There are worse gifts," she said. A silence settled that was not empty. Rain softened into a steady tap-tap, and the shop smelled of paper and lemon polish. He looked around, at the cramped aisles, the patchwork of titles. For the first time, he did not practice a face. His guard dropped in a way that made him look not smaller but human-sized. "Tell me your name," he said. She hesitated, then: "Miriam." "Miriam," he repeated, tasting it. "Miriam. That suits you. It's dignified. Firm. It sounds like someone who can reorder me." She snorted. "I am not in the business of reordering famous men." "No?" he said. "I was going to say 'soften' rather than 'reorder.' But reorder has... possibilities." He watched her with an interest that felt less hungry than curious. "Do you always dismantle charm work so fast? I had a plan here." "Plans are overrated," she said. "They assume the world will play along." He smiled, truly smiling now, a rare, uncalculated thing. "You assume the world will play along with your books. Different kinds of arrogance." She couldn't quite keep the corner of her mouth down. "I will call it conviction," she said. He sat back, towel forgotten across his lap. "You know, you should be in public relations. Or theatre. Or medicine." "Or in a bookshop," she said. "Where I can see people before they become stories." He stood, an almost-imperceptible gesture—deciding whether to go. "Miriam, I could... I could wait here. Quietly. I could buy a book. Support local commerce. Do something small and nonperformative." She met his eyes. For a heartbeat, the shop contracted to just their two faces and the soft sound of rain. "Just buy a book and stop narrating your life," she said. He grinned, sheepish. "That is probably the best instruction I've had all day." He wandered the aisles, fingers trailing across spines, and she watched with the professional curiosity of someone cataloguing behavior. He was careful in his selection, not because he feared judgement but because he liked to be seen as thoughtful. He picked a thin novel, its cover the faded blue of the sea, and carried it to the counter. "That one?" she asked. "Yes," he said. "I'd like to be someone who reads that one. Or who has read that one. Either will do." She rang him up with practiced indifference. "Five pounds twenty." He handed her a note and fumbled for coins like an actor missing a cue. "Keep the change. Do you have a loyalty program? A Tom Channing stamp card? How many stamps for a free hug?" She punched the till. "One free cup of tea for every serious book purchased. Hugs are extra." He smiled, small and private. "Then I'll collect. See you tomorrow, Miriam." "When's tomorrow for you?" she asked. He canted his head, thoughtfully. "Tomorrow's a press tour. Next week might be better. Or the week after. Fame is fickle. Plans are flexible." "Good," she said. "Words like 'next week' are practical. They're not promises." He took his towel, the charm subdued to something gentler. "Next week, then. If the tabloids don't swallow me whole. If they do, you can use the book as a eulogy." She snorted. "It will probably cause a fuss. It could increase footfall." He laughed, a soft, real sound. "You are impossible to flatter, Miriam. It's oddly appealing." "And you're impossible to ignore," she replied. "It's oddly exhausting." He paused at the door, hand on the handle. For a second he looked like a man turning a role inside out. Then he said, quieter than before, "Goodnight, then. And—" he hesitated — "be careful with my secrets." "I'll keep them between the pages," she said. The bell chimed as he left, a small, precise sound. She closed the ledger, looked at the card in her hand, then resumed her inventory. Outside, under the Cardiff rain, flashes stuttered like a bad film. He ducked his head and walked on, the noise of cameras filling the space he'd vacated, but not, for a moment, the space he'd left inside the shop.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a scene between a famous actor and a bookstore owner with strong attention to the requested character dynamics. The writing excels in establishing distinct voices for both characters - Tom with his theatrical, self-conscious charm and Miriam with her direct, unimpressed demeanor that masks an underlying interest. The dialogue is particularly strong, revealing character through speech patterns rather than exposition. Tom's lines are performative and self-aware ("I'm a mystery, wrapped in charm, wrapped in a towel"), while Miriam's responses are clipped and observant ("You like being liked. That's the trouble with being liked. It becomes a job."). This contrast effectively establishes their dynamic. The writer skillfully handles the requested character traits. Tom is portrayed as a charming rogue with a fragile ego who needs validation, shown through his persistent attempts to impress Miriam and his discomfort when she doesn't respond as expected. Miriam appears immune to his charm on the surface but shows subtle signs of being affected ("She couldn't quite keep the corner of her mouth down"). The prose balances description with dialogue well, using small physical details to convey emotional states without overexplaining. The Welsh setting is present but understated through references to Cardiff, the rain, and local postcards. However, there are a few weaknesses. Some metaphors feel slightly forced ("the bell above the door chimed like a secret"), and occasionally the prose becomes a bit too self-conscious. The ending, while avoiding an unrealistic romantic resolution, feels slightly abrupt after the rich interaction that precedes it. The chemistry between the characters builds naturally through their verbal sparring, creating tension without resorting to clichés. The piece effectively conveys how Tom's practiced charm falls away in the face of Miriam's directness, leading to genuine attraction rather than his usual performance. Overall, this is a sophisticated piece that handles the romance genre with subtlety and psychological insight, creating a scene that feels like part of a larger, compelling narrative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 82.0
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The underhold smelled of oil and old leather and the faint, metallic tang of blood—smells that belonged to the Morska more than any rose-scented salon could claim. Gas lamps, their mantles sputtering like tired lungs, lined the arched passage and threw long, nervous shadows that licked the flagstones. Aya’s gloved fingers brushed the door iron; it was colder than she expected, and her pulse answered like a struck bell. Katra’s breath was a small, sharp thing at her shoulder. Simeon’s shadow stood too straight, too prepared. They had slipped past sentries, bribed a locksmith for a single night’s breath, and spoken lies smooth enough to catch seals. For months Aya had navigated the guild’s underbellies like a sleepwalker, mapping its arteries by torchlight and whispered rumor. Tonight had been meant to be the claim: an ancient scythan blade, the heart of the guild’s authority, wrapped in runes older than the city’s statutes. Take the blade, and you took the right to name captains. Take the blade, and they were done with furtive meetings in basements; they would sit at the top table. The corridor opened into a vaulted hall, and the lamps there burned steady, deliberate as a judge’s stare. At its center, on a dais of blackened stone, stood a woman wrapped in a coat of brass and whale-leather, chains crossing her chest like the ribs of some slow-beating thing. Her hair was a crown of dark curls sprinkled with salt like iron filings; her eyes were all teeth when they smiled. She had been dead, in rumor and in the mouths of proteges who trafficked in whispers. Aya saw the leader of the Morska breathe. “Hands very clean for a young aristocrat,” the woman said, and the voice was silk lined with gravel. “You smell of drawing-room lavender and rummage-rooms alike. Come to the heart for a fancy, have you?” Aya’s throat worked. The mask under her cloak was still warm from her face; she had practiced the tilt that hid a mouth and left only the sentence of her eyes. The woman’s gaze skimmed Katra and Simeon, as if inventorying spoils. Behind her, five burly figures—gaunt to the point of rope—fell into a slow semi-circle, pistols and hooked knives glinting. They were the sort who trusted brass and balance over rumor and curse. One of them wore a little brass monocle that clicked with tiny, satisfied noises. The scythan artifact they had sought gleamed on a plinth to the leader’s left, secured in an array of gears and iron wards. Katra’s hand went to the hilt of her blade. Simeon’s fingers brushed the gearing of his cross-shot. Aya, who had practiced a dozen different answers, found her voice small and precise. “My lady—” she started, and the title tasted like a lead coin. It was a title she might never have used in real parlors, but it fit here, among clawed men and kept secrets. “We did not expect—” “Expect me to be in the underhold?” the leader said. Her smile opened like a trap. “You should know better than most that a properly run guild keeps its foundations sound. Arrests are theater. Bodies make headlines. I prefer quieter work.” There was a movement at the edge of Aya’s sight: a hand like a shadow, a quick rise of coiled leather. A rope looped, silvered, and then fell across Aya’s throat so quickly she tasted metal. It was not force alone; the rope hummed with some small, compelling thrumm—brass wires wound with a runic lattice that made the skin pucker. The thing in the leader’s hand wasn’t merely a weapon; it was a confession waiting to be read. Aya struggled and found the webbing of the trap cold around her jaw. Katra swore, a sound like a snapped twig. Simeon lunged and met a baton of oil-pitted iron against his temple; stars bled into his vision. “Easy,” the leader said. “We played the law for a time to learn what their dogs knew. Your fancy games ended with a clockwork, child.” She stepped closer, and her perfume was of pipe-smoke and winter meat. “Unmask her.” A gaunt man with the monocle obliged. The glove that brushed Aya’s cheek was warm with the pulse of a city that had never feared sorrow. The motion was quick, professional; the cloth of the mask peelable like stage makeup. Aya’s heart climbed into her throat as though wanting to be free. When the leather fell away, the hall inhaled. The leader’s lashes dropped, and with a swift, amused cruelty she reached up and wrenched back Aya’s chin until the light fell across the girl’s features. Gaslight picked out the aristocratic bone, the faint scar along the jaw where a previous night’s misadventure had closed badly. The leader’s mouth opened in something that was almost tender. “You,” she said. “The ghastly little belle who walks salons and picks locks. Aya of the Velis house. My, my. The city has better jokes than I suspected.” Katra spat. “You knew.” “Of course I knew. The underhold is not merely stone and steel; it’s gossip, and ledger entries, and the way a noble’s carriage avoids certain streets.” The leader’s fingers were slow as she turned Aya’s face toward the plinth. “And I knew you liked to play with things no conversation should touch. The immateria. What your mother did. Such dangerous hobbies for a drawing-room girl.” Heat flooded Aya’s face—not from the ropes but from a raw, private dread. Her mother’s execution had been the one true compass of her life; its shadow bent everything. She had thought her thefts, her nights, would remain a small, dangerous secret. She had not counted on the leader’s reach, on the way the guild paled and swallowed rumor as quickly as it ate coin. “You’ll be put out,” Katra snarled. “You can’t parade her—” “Oh, but I can.” The leader’s eyes glinted with a cruel sort of commerce. “Imagine the convenience. A noble’s daughter, revealed as an immateria practitioner, in league with thieves? The magistrates will clamber like hungry gulls. The houses will turn their backs. Many of your friends will find it easier to forget your name than to remember your crimes. And you, Miss Velis—” She dropped the title like a lashing. “You have value. Hostage value. Perhaps that will make you…useful.” Aya’s jaw clenched. The word “hostage” scraped like a stone down her insides. Value. She felt suddenly exposed, as if a price tag had been sewn to the inside of her waistcoat. She had learned the contours of negotiation in the salons as well as in the alleys: a look, a withheld laugh, the correct name dropped at the right time. Desperation made for blunt instruments. “You want leverage,” Aya said, and the voice came out steadier than she felt. “I can give you what you want—names, accounts, secrets.” She watched the leader’s face for the flicker that betrayed surprise. It came—an infinitesimal lift at the brow. “My access is…legitimate. House ledgers, patron lists. I know where their smugglers hide their ledgers. There are other families who dabble in illegal magicks. Expose them and the magistracy will have more than enough to string out every captain in this room.” The leader’s laugh was short. “And we should believe a silver-blooded girl who has been living a double life since childhood? What proof do you offer? Words are cheap in a city of thieves, Miss Velis.” “Proof is expensive,” Aya said. She let her eyes drop to the plinth. The scythan blade lay like a small, black promise, teeth of rune-etched metal peeking from under a glass dome. A ward hissed at the tiny of her wrist. She tried to feel for the immateria—the thin, cold thread of it that had been her mother’s gift—but the ropes tasted of iron and binding. Her hands were bound, but her throat was free. “One thing,” she said. “The Velis ledger contains payments to the guild from certain…convenient parties. There are entries I can forge—explain away as shadow accounting. You take me to your allies—arrange for safe passage—and I leave you a map. A ledger of names.” “Convenient,” the leader echoed. She tapped her chin where a little brass stud had been hammered into the skin—an old custom among guildmasters. “You ask for mercy and offer us the leverage we already possess in exchange for a guarantee of your life. Most amusing.” Behind the leader, a young guard—his face unscarred by experience—leaned forward like a curious child. “She’s sly,” he offered. “If she’s Velis, there are houses that’ll pay to keep her quiet. Or kill her sweetly and no one asks after the ledger.” “The magistrates prefer spectacle,” Katra said, the bitter note in her voice like a file. “But they also prefer no one starts a revolution over a girl. They like their conduits of power tidy.” Simeon, still rubbing at his temple, found his voice and it was softer than usual. “Aya—” he began, and then stopped, because there was no map in the world that led them out of this room clean. The leader’s gaze had slid back to Aya’s face, softer now, not unkind—a predator appreciating the strength of a worthy bird. “You have something worth keeping,” she said finally. “But understand this: the guild does not bargain from weakness. It uses it. We will take your proof, your velvet bargains, and we will sew them into a net that keeps the magistracy from poking where it hurts. You will be kept until the city forgets who you are, or until you are no longer useful.” Aya swallowed. The air tasted like iron and old spells. She thought of her mother—of rope and the last ugly scrape of the noose—of salons that now smelled of cunning and pity. She had long ago chosen the night three times over, and now the night had chosen a ledger to balance upon her. “If you think to kill me after you squeeze your coin from this,” she said, “make it quick. I would rather not be caged to teach other daughters of the city about the price of curiosity.” The leader smiled, and for the briefest instant the scythan artifact caught her reflection and made it monstrous. “Oh, my dear,” she said. “We teach lessons and make bargains. You are both—dangerous and useful. That is what keeps one alive, in our world.” She gestured, and the guard with the monocle stepped forward to unbind Aya’s wrists, not out of kindness but to mock the tension in display. “Bring them to the lock cells. I will have my men prepare the ledger, and perhaps a letter to the magistrates. You will learn what the world does when it knows your name.” As they were led away—Katra hot with fury, Simeon with the quiet of a man watching ruin unfold—Aya dared to lift her eyes to the plinth one last time. The scythan blade sat untouched, like a promise that would not keep. Beneath the lamps, the shadows seemed to shift and whisper, and in Aya’s chest a thing cold and ancient unfurled—the immateria, prickling like a storm at the edge of dawn. She swallowed the urge to call it, to pull a dark thing through and slit silence with its teeth. For now, bargaining would have to do. “You will pay for this,” Katra hissed, but the leader’s laugh was already rolling behind them like a wheel of brass. “Perhaps,” the leader said, as they were led away into the bone-deep cold of the lock cells. “Or perhaps you’ve all arrived at precisely the right moment.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response demonstrates a strong command of Victorian-inspired fantasy with gothic horror elements. The writer has created a vivid underworld setting with appropriate sensory details that establish the gritty, industrial aesthetic requested in the prompt. The gas lamps, brass, oil, and leather create a tangible atmosphere that feels authentic to the whalepunk genre. The piece follows the requested story beats faithfully: Aya and her companions enter the underhold, discover the supposedly incarcerated guild leader, Aya is captured and unmasked, and she attempts to negotiate based on her value as a hostage. The writer has maintained third-person past tense throughout and incorporated Aya's internal monologue effectively. The dialogue is one of the stronger elements, with distinct voices for each character. The guild leader speaks with authority and a cruel sophistication, while Aya's speech reflects her dual nature as both aristocrat and thief. The dialogue incorporates period-appropriate formality and slang that enhances the Victorian aesthetic. However, there are moments where the prose becomes somewhat purple and overwrought. Phrases like "her eyes were all teeth when they smiled" and "the voice was silk lined with gravel" are evocative but occasionally tip into excessive metaphor. Some descriptions feel unnecessarily ornate, such as "the scythan artifact caught her reflection and made it monstrous," which doesn't quite land with the impact intended. The characters demonstrate reasonable complexity. Aya's internal conflict about her dual identity and her mother's execution provides emotional depth. The guild leader is portrayed as calculating and ruthless but with a certain pragmatism that makes her believable. Katra and Simeon are less developed but serve their roles adequately. The piece successfully incorporates the requested worldbuilding elements, particularly the contrast between technology ("brass and oil and steel") and the feared, barely understood magicka (here called "immateria"). The ropes with brass wires and runic lattice that suppress Aya's magical abilities are a nice touch that reinforces this theme. The pacing is generally effective, though there are moments where the narrative momentum slows due to excessive description. The ending avoids a simplistic resolution, instead suggesting complications to come, which adds depth to the story. Overall, this is a competent piece of genre fiction that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an engaging scene with appropriate atmosphere and characterization. Its strengths lie in its dialogue, worldbuilding, and adherence to the requested aesthetic, while its weaknesses include occasional purple prose and some moments of telling rather than showing. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 88.7
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A lazy ceiling fan barely stirs the smoky air inside the bar. The neon sign outside bleeds pink and blue through the grime on the windows, and the smell of spilled beer and stale smoke clings to everything like a second skin. The place is the kind the universe forgets about: cracked vinyl booths, a jukebox mid-melody, and an ancient dartboard nobody bothers to use. Spike Spiegel slips in like he owns half the dark alleys of the city — long coat, cigarette hanging from the corner of his mouth, one hand already seeking the familiar comfort of the pack in his pocket. He looks hungry, but lazy about it; the hunger is always a dull ache under his bones. She’s already at the bar, two stools down from the end. Revy — mouth a permanent sneer, hair clipped up, shorts scandalously short and a dragon tattoo coiling around her right arm — is cleaning two pistols with a rag that’s seen better days. Her movements are efficient and raw, like everything about her. A bottle is half-empty by her elbow; she drinks in that single-minded way she drinks and shoots. The bartender avoids looking directly at her. He knows better. Spike pauses, takes in the room with a gambler’s detachment, and then slides onto a stool a polite distance away. He orders something cheap and takes the cigarette that’s been his familiar companion out of his mouth for a moment to confirm a name. “Two Hands,” he says, voice lazy but carrying like smoke. Revy doesn’t look up. “You got a problem, pretty boy?” “No. Just the same job, I hear.” He gestures toward the printed warrant laid flat on the bar between them as if it’s nothing more than a napkin. “Named a price.” She snorts, the sound a wet mockery. “Those syndicate types pay good when they want someone dead who annoys them.” She flicks her rag and shows him the small, specific scuff on her pistol slide. “You trying to tell me you’re not here for the money?” Spike hums. “Mostly. And for the experience. Lucky me, I get both.” He lets his half-smile sit there, the kind that never reaches his eyes. He smokes the cigarette down, ash trembling at the tip. “Name’s Spiegel. Spike Spiegel. You?” “Rebecca.” The way she says it is a little bare, like she’s testing whether his hearing is worth anything. “But most call me Revy.” They circle like two predators that have learned to read the same trails. The bar’s other patrons pretend they don’t notice as the air between the two thickens with the old, dangerous thing that happens when two people who handle violence for a living discover the same kind of spark in another: not warmth so much as a flare of recognition. They both know what arms, and hands, and a steadied breath can do. They both know how cheap promises taste. “You snowy-eyed pretty boys from the Bebop crew usually have that haunted look,” Revy says eventually, tapping the tip of a cigarette against the bar like punctuation. “You been in some fucked-up love story or something?” Spike gives her a lazy once-over and a shrug. “Something like that. I’ve already died once. Not in a hurry to do it again unless the scenery’s worth it.” “Whatever happens, happens,” she echoes, mocking and almost fond. It’s dangerous to find your quote repeated by someone you don’t trust. Spike smiles a little more genuinely at that. They talk terms through cheap whiskey and cheaper jokes. Each lie is a test; each truth is a loaded gun left leaning against the jukebox. Revy wants half up front and the rest when the target’s heart stops. Spike’s tactical mind evaluates angles and exits with a gambler’s impatience for risk. He offers to split the job evenly and to let her take point; she grunts but agrees — because if there’s anyone she’d rather have at her back it’s someone who can move like water and take a bullet without blinking. Because he’s got that syndicate past and she understands what that means without asking. Night dilates; the bartender keeps putting glasses down in front of them and both occupants of the bar forget they’re doing anything but sizing each other up. Revy has a laugh that’s almost a bark when Spike brags about a narrowly improvised escape that involved a hot air vent and a very pained lieutenant. Spike laughs because she’s laughing and because she’s not mollifying or expecting praise. There’s an edge of competitiveness between them, and it’s honest and loud in a way both find… not unpleasant. “You don’t trust easily, do you?” Spike says at one point, voice half-mirth, half-probe. Revy’s eyes narrow. “Trust you to do what? Betray you to the highest bidder? Nah. I don’t do trust. I do survival. Pick your lane, pretty boy.” Her fingers flex on the pistol in her lap, a casual possession that speaks of inevitability. “Same,” Spike answers. “I don’t like attachments. They complicate things.” He flicks ash and watches it land in the glass like it’s the only thing that matters. “You kidding? You’ve got a whole ship full of them,” Revy points out, incredulous and a little annoyed. “You got a crew. You got… whatever the hell you got.” He shrugs. “They’re an anchorage. I pretend they’re not.” Revy clinks her bottle against his glass — a mock salute — and the contact is an excuse to linger closer than etiquette allows. Her skin smells like cigarettes and something metallic beneath it: oil, adrenaline, old blood tales. Spike feels that pull that every bullet-crazy person knows; it’s not romantic, not really. It’s respect dressed up in dangerous clothing. They take the case the same night. The target — a slick collector of black-market tech — is holed up in a third-rate motel near the waterfront. The place smells of mildew and something worse. Spike and Revy arrive separately, two punctures in the night that converge in the motel’s flickering hallway. Revy’s twin pistols catch the dim light; Spike’s silhouette is a lazy thing, one hand in his pocket, smoking. Their pact is wordless and brittle, like a promise written on safety glass. Inside the room, the target is half-awake and very much surprised to see two legends of the underworld pointing at him. Words are unnecessary; both know how this will end. Revy moves like a shadow, precise. Spike moves like a mirage, economy wrapped in unpredictability. The target reaches for a bedside drawer; a round from one of Revy’s pistols bores a hole through his hand like a punctuation mark. Spike steps forward and the man goes limp. But when the man rolls, his fingers knock loose a phone that slides under the bed into darkness. It’s a small thing, but the possibility of someone calling for backup hangs between them like a live wire. Spike’s prosthetic eye, a dull gleam in the low light, tracks the movement poorly; he relies on instinct, on rhythm. Revy curses, quick as a snapping wire, and goes for the phone. The shot that wasn’t meant to come sings from the next room — a splintered door where a silhouette prompts a muscle memory both of them share: immediate cover, immediate suppression. The place erupts. Bullets chew into plaster and dusty lamps. Revy answers with a staccato of twin fire; Spike’s pistol arcs in a slower, balletic rhythm, one shot finding an angle where Revy’s two miss. The fireworks are ugly and precise. They find cover back-to-back at the motel bedroom door with a heap of broken furniture between them. For a few breaths they are synchronized, the wordless choreography of people who die for a living. The adrenaline scrapes through them like sand, leaving both wired and, in a strange way, comforted. “Nice shooting,” Revy growls through a grin that’s teeth and danger. “Same to you,” Spike answers, the cigarette between his lips somehow intact. He gives a playful, meaningless bow that’s more reflex than humor. “Two Hands, officially.” They secure the room and check the phone, answer calls, collect the sweat-thin reward. The job is done. They both know how the story beats will go after: split, exchange quick fists of cash, and the world resets. But neither leaves. The bar had taught them a different rhythm, and something heavier than the money keeps their boots rooted. Revy proposes a motel room. Not the one they just cleared; the other one down the hall where the sheets are newer and the walls don’t bow as obviously. She’s quiet when she asks — softer in a way she rarely is — as if she’s testing water she’s never tested before. Spike’s smile doesn’t reach the haunted crease near his right eye, but he agrees with the casual fatalism that is his armor. “Whatever happens, happens,” he repeats, because it’s something to say. Inside the dim motel room, the atmosphere twists tighter. A bottle halves again between them. Revy lounges across the foot of the bed like she owns the world and Spike leans against the headboard, the room’s weak lamp painting them in tired gold. There’s a small, aching closeness between them: war-veteran camaraderie and the ugly, electric flavor of unacknowledged desire. Their cigarettes burn low. They drink more. They talk less. At some point the conversation drifts to scars and ghosts — Revy’s is a closed fist around a childhood she never shows, Spike’s a slow drift toward a woman he left and a past that keeps tugging at him. They trade fragments of confession like daggers being laid bare. Vulnerabilities are dangerous and both of them know that. The clock drips toward morning. Revy’s hand strays to a pistol on the nightstand, not in a paranoid tic but as the only language she fully trusts. Spike’s hand moves to his holster in a mirror of that same mistrust. They sit in that symmetrical silence until the air itself seems to hold its breath. Then the room’s tension becomes a line drawn in gunmetal: neither will be the first to fully lower their weapon and likely their heart. “Don’t think I’m soft,” Revy mutters, voice barely audible. “Don’t ever think that.” Spike’s smile is a small eclipse of humor and sorrow. “I don’t.” He taps ash into an empty bottle. They are equals in ways that don’t comfort. The standoff is less about the guns and more about the truths they guard. They breathe in the same room, tipped toward the same moment. Revy’s thumb twitches on her pistol, Spike’s eye tracks the movement like an old reflex. The motel is a pressure cooker and the tension they share has the viscosity of gasoline. Then, impossibly, Revy laughs — a short, sharp sound — and lets the pistol rest on her thigh. Spike exhales, and the cigarette between his fingers goes out. They both know this peace is temporary. They both know that tomorrow they will be strangers again, competitors again, survivors who cross paths in alleys when the world needs blood and favors and money. But for a stolen breath in that motel room, they allow the quiet to be what it is: an unspoken truce. Revy flicks her lighter and the brief flare exposes the dragon tattoo on her arm, the hard line of muscle and the soft nothing behind her eyes. Spike watches with the fatalism of someone who’s already died once and keeps finding reasons to come back. He moves closer by a fraction that is almost a mistake and almost everything. The distance between them stays measured, unresolved. Outside, the neon hums on and the world keeps its bony teeth. Inside, a lazy fan keeps turning. They do not say the words. They do not promise to trust. They keep their guns where they can see them and their hearts where they can’t. Their unfinished things curl like smoke, delicate and relentless, and for now that’s enough.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of both characters from their respective universes while creating a believable scenario where they might interact. The author demonstrates a strong understanding of both Spike and Revy's personalities, backgrounds, and speech patterns. The prose is atmospheric and evocative, particularly in establishing the seedy bar setting and the gritty motel room. The descriptions are economical yet vivid: "The neon sign outside bleeds pink and blue through the grime on the windows" effectively sets the noir-ish tone. The author skillfully uses sensory details to immerse the reader in this underworld. Character portrayal is particularly strong. Spike's laid-back fatalism ("Whatever happens, happens") contrasts nicely with Revy's aggressive pragmatism. Their dialogue feels authentic to their established personalities, with Revy's profanity-laced directness and Spike's laconic observations. The author captures Revy's "Two Hands" reputation and Spike's syndicate background without excessive exposition. The unresolved sexual tension is handled with subtlety and restraint. Rather than forcing physical intimacy, the author builds tension through shared professional respect, mutual wariness, and the characters' inability to fully lower their guards. The motel room standoff effectively symbolizes their emotional standoff. The action sequence is well-executed, showing both characters' combat styles: "Revy's twin pistols catch the dim light; Spike's silhouette is a lazy thing, one hand in his pocket, smoking." Their complementary fighting styles during the shootout demonstrate how they might work together despite their trust issues. There are a few minor weaknesses. Some sentences become slightly overwrought: "The bar had taught them a different rhythm, and something heavier than the money keeps their boots rooted." The piece occasionally veers toward purple prose, particularly in metaphorical descriptions of tension. The ending, while thematically appropriate, feels slightly abrupt. Overall, this is a sophisticated character study that honors both source materials while creating something new. The author balances action, character development, and atmosphere effectively, creating a crossover that feels natural rather than forced. The unresolved ending suits both characters, who are defined by their inability to fully connect despite their similarities. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 89.1
Prompt:
Folk Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond."
