"You can be whatever you are," I said, wanting to say so many things but keeping them sparse, because truth sometimes needs to be blunt and gentle at the same time. "And I can be—" I paused, because even saying it felt like rearranging a furniture that had been nailed into my conceptions. "I can be attracted to you. Not to a label. To you." He swallowed, a little sound like he’d taken a drink. "Even if I change the—like, tomorrow?" "Even if you change as many times as you want." It felt dangerous to be that patient out loud. I think he heard it as both permission and pledge. He looked smaller, relieved, as if I had tossed a rope over something he couldn't climb alone. We returned to the trays because that is what we were there to do. The conversation folded back into the mechanics—the timer, the agitation of the tray, the slow rise of contrast. When the print came out in the stop bath, it smelled like iron and memory. Elliot's fingers lingered at the edge of the paper like they wanted to touch it and then decide. He hummed again, that little sound like a metronome keeping us in time. "You know," he said in between notes, "I used to think people who changed were… flaky. Like my dad. Now I think I judged a lot." His voice had a new patience with himself. "I don't want to be someone who hurts people. I also don't want to lie to myself." "Then don't," I said. It was both trite and radical. A simple exhale of consent that sounded like a vow in that cavernous red room. I surprised myself with how much I wanted his self-discovery to be clean and joyful. Part of me wanted to take the reins and brand his path with my enthusiasm, but another part wanted to wait and let him choose his pace. Maybe this was the difference between being decisive and being domineering. Maybe being an adult meant learning to love someone who is still a work-in-progress without painting over their edges. He looked at me then, properly looked—as if he had been curating a face in his mind and I had finally stepped into the frame. The red light softened his pupils to black coins. The jacket sleeves were pushed up just so; the cuffs revealed a slender wrist with ink smudges, the residue of his other obsessions. "What are you thinking?" he asked. "That this is one of my better semester pairings," I said, and I meant it with a grin that probably read as cocky if there had been any cool light left. But this was true: he made me braver the way flint makes fire, and his uncertainty made honesty inevitable. "Also, that your humming is better than most soundtracks." He snorted, but it was shy. "You're allowed to be bossy," he said, "just not mean." "Deal," I said, and we sealed it with the kind of agreement that's less formal than a contract and more binding in a lab of chemicals and shared confidences. The final print went into the fixer, and by the time we rinsed it under the cold faucet, the conversation had wandered through a dozen conditional futures—pronouns, wardrobes, crushes and feared abandonments. None of it was tidy. Neither smiling nor trembling, Elliot moved through the room like someone trying on lives. When he left later, the corridor swallowed his small figure. He turned at the doorway and gave me a small wave, an afterthought question. I wanted to chase him down there and tell him that I would learn any pronouns he needed me to, that I would be patient and fierce, protective and absent of dictation. Instead I watched him go and promised myself to be the kind of person who could hold his hand—literally or otherwise—if asked. On my way out, I flicked off the safelight. The darkroom blinked back into ordinary light and the prints settled into permanence. I walked out into the corridor with a new kind of appetite—less about defining and more about discovering. I pressed my palm to the paper I'd made and realized the image we'd developed together had nothing to do with how the world labeled him. It was about the chemistry—two elements reacting, changing, neither losing themselves entirely. Outside, the moon was a thin coin. I thought about other people I’d loved who had fit the edges I expected. I thought, too, about what it would mean to be attracted to someone who rearranged themselves like furniture, whose style and stance might shift with the seasons. It was disorienting in a way that made me feel, exhilaratingly, like a beginner again. I hummed as I walked, an unfamiliar melody stumbling out of me—part comfort, part question. Somewhere behind me the darkroom held our prints and our promises, the red light gone but the revelation glowing like a latent image, waiting for the right chemical to bring it fully into being.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures Dani's perspective as she navigates her complex attraction to Elliot during their darkroom session. The piece effectively establishes the intimate atmosphere of the darkroom with its red light creating a "confessional" space as requested in the prompt. The characterization of Dani is strong and consistent throughout. Her assertive personality comes through clearly in her internal monologue ("I have never been the sort to knock gently. I commandeer the conversation, the playlist, the final projects"), while showing her struggle to restrain this tendency when interacting with Elliot. The writer skillfully portrays her internal conflict between wanting to take charge and giving Elliot agency in his self-discovery. Elliot's character is well-developed through Dani's eyes - his quiet intellect, unconventional style, and vulnerability are all conveyed effectively. The dialogue between them feels natural and reveals their developing relationship in a believable way. Elliot's disclosure about questioning his gender identity is handled with sensitivity and authenticity. The prose is elegant and evocative, with strong imagery that enhances the mood: "The darkroom devoured the rest of the world and spat out a halo of red." The writer uses the darkroom setting and photography metaphors effectively throughout, creating a cohesive thematic framework. Descriptions like "Watching pictures reveal themselves was a kind of transubstantiation" create rich sensory experiences. The narrative successfully explores Dani's complex emotions - her protective instincts, confusion about what Elliot's gender questioning means for her own identity, and her growing attraction. The piece captures the "tender awkwardness" requested in the prompt through both dialogue and Dani's reflections. There are moments where the prose becomes slightly purple or overwrought, with metaphors occasionally stacking too densely. For example, "I felt this wind through the small of my ribs, an involuntary protective thing that wanted to wrap around his shoulders" feels somewhat overwritten. The ending effectively brings closure while maintaining the sense of uncertainty and possibility in their relationship. Dani's final reflections about being "attracted to someone who rearranged themselves like furniture" and feeling "like a beginner again" nicely capture her growth and the uncharted territory they're exploring together. Overall, this is an accomplished piece that fulfills the prompt requirements with nuanced characterization, evocative prose, and emotional depth. It successfully captures the complex dynamics of attraction, identity, and vulnerability requested in the prompt. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 89.3
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Trevi spilled light like melted coins. Tourists orbited the fountain with insistently cheerful cameras; couples posed as though love could be bottled; a child attempted, with grim concentration, to feed pigeons. Ben had one hand on the guidebook and the other in his pocket, the map of Rome printed on his face in the careful crease between his brows. Sabbatical, he told himself. Observe. There was a rhythm to this—notes worth transcribing in his head, not to be disturbed. A motorcycle threaded through the crowd like a fish through reeds. It was too close. Ben looked up just in time to see a helmeted head, a flash of black leather, and the bike's tail slicing past him with such intimate precision his guidebook wavered and nearly flipped into the fountain. "Scusi!" The rider's voice was a wink in Italian—rapid, melodic, edges sharpened to laughter. "Maremma, you and your maps—watch where you stare, bravo!" Ben's apology burst out in English, thick as custard. "Oh my—I'm terribly sorry. I didn't—" "Non tuo problema, inglese studioso," she said, braking a footboard-length away and dismounting like a cat. She tucked the helmet under her arm and leaned a hip against the bike. Her hair escaped its confines in a deliberate mess; her eyes did nothing to hide amusement or assessment. She smelled faintly of espresso and something metallic—leather and engine oil and a trace of mischief. Ben swallowed, mortified. "I'm Ben. Ben Avery. From—England. I'm so sorry about almost—" "You almost drowned the guidebook," she said, and smiled. It was not unkind and it wasn't kind either. "Alessandra." "Alessandra." He repeated the name as if testing new currency. "Delighted. I mean—pleasure. You ride very—" "Fast?" She raised an eyebrow. "Yes. Sometimes too fast. Sometimes perfect." She spoke with that swift Roman cadence that made even complaints sound like promises. Her hands were small and quick, nails chipped, a scar on the knuckle of her left index finger that flashed when she shrugged. Ben offered a hesitant smile. "You scared me. For the fountain, I mean." She laughed—a bright, short burst. "We're in Rome, Inglese. Scared is part of the sightseeing." An impulse hummed in her eyes, something dangerous and giddy. She reached out and plucked the guidebook from his hands. "Let me see—'Ben Avery, a day in Rome'… ah, very dry. You need a livelier itinerary." Ben felt his cheeks warm. "I—I'm supposed to—observe. For lecture notes. For—" "For how to fall asleep in front of a slide projector?" She flipped a page. "No. Put that away." It was half an order, half a dare. "Come." He hesitated—the polite, rule-following syllables in his skull tugging at the leash. He could say no. He could watch her rev and disappear down alleys like a comet. Instead, he found himself pocketing his guidebook and falling into step beside her bike. They left the Trevi's tourist tide behind and collided immediately with the street's real Rome: laundry lines, old men shouting bets at a bar, the scent of frying fish. Alessandra rode with unbothered audacity, threading narrow cobbles so close to boutique awnings her shoulders brushed silk scarves. Ben kept his hands folded in the pockets of his coat, observing the subtle muscles of her jaw when she judged a turn, the way she negotiated space without the slightest apology. "You always this reckless?" he asked once they were parked at a piazza where the pigeons had surrendered to sleep. "Sometimes," she said. "Depends who's watching. Depends if there's something shiny to steal." He blinked. "Steal?" Her mouth went up at one corner. "Kleptomania—big word, yes? I say I like small excitements. I like objects that choose me." He pictured her, nimble and secret-handed, slipping trinkets into pockets—a child's red balloon, a cheap brass key, maybe a souvenir coin. He imagined her hands again, the way she had taken the guidebook, the quickness that bordered on playfulness and trespass. "You don't—" he started, then smiled in spite of himself, "—you don't sound like a criminal justice case study." "No," she said breezily. "People give me things. Or things find me. The city's full of things looking for new owners." They moved through Rome like a pair of mismatched shoes found under a café table. Alessandra pushed him to the eccentric places his guidebook would never list: a tiny bar with more Presbyterians than patrons, where the owner slipped olives into Ben's hands and muttered half in English that Ben's jacket made him look like a university lecturer and thus dangerously respectable; a stairwell where she whispered a litany of saints' names backwards, and for a moment, Ben felt the vertigo of time. At the Campo de' Fiori market, she extracted a lemon so yellow it might have been born to order and began juggling it between them, unbothered by vendors. "Taste," she commanded. He bit; it was unexpectedly sweet, the kind of flavor that made him blink. She watched him, satisfied. "Why me?" he asked later, while they sat on the steps above the Tiber, legs dangling, the city confessing itself in the quiet between their words. "Because you are polite," Alessandra said simply. "Because you looked like you could use a little trouble. And you smell like rain." Ben laughed, startled into doing so by the casual intimacy of her observation. "I only smell like rain because I washed my hair and forgot to bring an umbrella." "And because you're British," she added, like an afterthought that landed like a feather. The way she toyed with him made him oddly giddy. He found himself shedding the polite hesitations as the day wore on. When she led him into a dim courtyard, past a sign that read 'Private—No Entry', he hesitated. "Please?" she said, with the single small animal look of someone who adored being refused and rarely was. "Just one courtyard. There is a fountain with cats." Ben pictured his sabbatical notes mutating into a scandalous travelogue. He pictured his department head's raised brow. He pictured his own practical shoes, which he had bought in Cambridge, scuffing Rome's forbidden stones. He allowed himself the small rebellion and followed. Inside the courtyard the fountain was indeed guarded by cats—plump and dignified, indifferent to human law. Alessandra crouched and stroked one between the ears, and it purred like a contented engine. She popped her head up and said, "You should see how some tourists look at me. Like I am a story they haven't read yet. Dangerous anthologies, full of missing pages." "Do you want to be read?" Ben asked. She tilted her head. "Sometimes I want to be an open book. Sometimes I want to be the bookmark. Today I'm a parable. Or maybe just short stories." They were interrupted by a voice that threaded from the archway like a familiar bell. "Alessandra? For heaven's sake—" The speaker was a man in his fifties, tanned, hair combed back with the care of someone who'd once mattered in an old Roman newspaper. He wore a suit that had seen better decades and a face that kept the city's wrinkles as if for safekeeping. "Marco," Alessandra said, a light shift in her posture. "What a miserable expression." Marco's eyes slid to Ben and flicked with the practiced readability of the locals. "Ah. New friend. Tourist? Student? Preacher?" "Ben. Ben Avery," Ben said, stumbling into the format of introductions. Marco reached out a hand with the kind of grip that had closed many a deal and stolen even more affection. "Enchanté. And you," he added with exaggerated courtesy, "should be wary. Alessandra is a charming liar, a habitual thief of the small and necessary. Better to keep your pockets zipped." Her laugh, a small chime, disagreed. "Marco, you dramatize. I pinch a ribbon now and then. It keeps me on my toes. Or, my friend, your watch seconds pass, and I take a minute back." "Watch your minutes, Alessandra," Marco said, mock sternness not quite covering warmth. He leaned closer to Ben, conspiratorial. "She's not a monster. She is—complicated. And she has a soft place like a magpie in a cathedral. But—" his gaze sharpened back on her with a gentleness that carried an unreadable history. "—do not let her teach you to jump without looking." Ben swallowed. The warning slid into him like a pebble into a river—small, making ripples. For the first time that day, the spark that had been all fun began to gloss with a hint of consequence. He looked to Alessandra for a reaction. She shrugged, but it wasn't a dismissal. "Marco, this is Ben. Ben, this is Marco, who spends his afternoons telling stories about my mother as if she were a saint. Marco says things because he is dramatic. He is a poet without papers." Marco winked. "I write. For my sins." They parted with the old man's flourish, and Alessandra turned to Ben. "See? Told you. I have a file. People say paperwork," she said, and then added softly, "He used to be my father's friend. He knows where I hide my better sins." "Are they sins like—taking lemons from the market?" Ben asked, a laugh bubbling up—lighter now, edged with an understanding he didn't yet own. "Like taking stolen moments," she said. "That's worse." The day folded into afternoon like a map refolding itself under capable hands. Alessandra escalated their mischief—dragging him into a Vespa race that was more howl than competition, lifting his hand to steal a glance at a fresco through a forbidden window, slipping a small bronze compass into his coat pocket at a secondhand stall and tucking the cashier's bemused expression in her back pocket like a receipt. Ben discovered he could be daring in small increments: he swore—quietly—on a narrow bridge when his shoe slipped; he agreed, without muttering a risk assessment, to a vin santo tasted in a doorframe lit by a single bulb; he let his laugh unfurl when Alessandra told a story about a nun who once stole cherries from the gardens of a cardinal and prayed with her mouth full. As they reached the station where their paths would diverge, twilight painted the city a forgiving mauve. Ben's hands were desert-warm from the engine and the day's nervous energy. He clutched the small bronze compass in his palm; it had the cheap weight of a souvenir but all the gravity of an emblem. They stood at the threshold, the evening's promise closing like a curtain that wanted to be reopened. Alessandra unbuckled her helmet and held it against her chest. The mischievous spark in her eyes had softened into something human, less a blade than a halo. "This has been the most inefficient day of my life," Ben said, which for him was praise. "For me, the most efficient," she replied. "You followed when you should've said no. You hugged an outlaw of minutes. You stole...experience." Ben laughed, a sound made of the day's misadventures. "Am I—in trouble?" "Maybe," she said, then added, as if offering him a map with a blot of ink where X might have been, "Or maybe you're just cursed with curiosity. Either way, don't tell Marco I told you my sins. He loses pleasure then." He stepped closer instinctively, emboldened by something that felt like the beginning and the end of a sentence all at once. "Will I see you again?" Alessandra's smile flexed in a way that could be coaxed into promise or propriety. "Rome is small for certain meanings," she said. "Look where the coins fall. I may be near. Or I may have taken a bus. Or a pocket. Or a life." Ben's fingers brushed the compass again. "Then I'll look." She stood on her tiptoes, almost reaching for his mouth and then deciding better of it. Instead she kissed his cheek—quick, like a seal of a pack of postcards. It was public and private and tasted like lemon and burnt espresso. As she swung onto her motorcycle and threaded into the city like a secret, Ben watched her go, every sense acute. He realized with a slow, dawning thrill that his guidebook lay back at Trevi, wet and still open. He thought of the coins in the fountain—promises people made to futures they couldn't quite believe in—and he wondered which one he'd been throwing today. Marco's warning curled in the back of his mind, warm and sharp both. Alessandra had been a lesson not easily categorized: a thief of ordinary moments, a thief perhaps of him if he let her. He felt disoriented, magnetized, like a compass gone slightly, marvellously wrong. He walked back toward the river, palms open, the bronze compass heavy with a purpose he couldn't yet name. In the city of stolen vistas and lingering promises, he had been pickpocketed of the safe, scholarly life he had expected on sabbatical. And he was smiling about the theft.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably well-crafted contemporary romance that successfully captures the essence of a chance encounter in Rome. The writing demonstrates exceptional skill in creating vivid imagery, establishing distinct character voices, and developing a compelling narrative arc within the constraints of the prompt. The characterization is particularly strong. Alessandra emerges as a fully realized character - fiery, impulsive, and enigmatic with her klepto tendencies subtly revealed through actions rather than exposition. Ben's transformation from cautious academic to willing adventurer feels organic and well-paced. Their contrasting personalities create natural tension and chemistry that drives the narrative forward. The prose style is sophisticated without becoming pretentious. The author employs evocative sensory details that immerse the reader in Rome's atmosphere: "The Trevi spilled light like melted coins" and descriptions of "laundry lines, old men shouting bets at a bar, the scent of frying fish." These details create a tangible sense of place. Dialogue is exceptional, revealing character through distinct speech patterns. Alessandra's "rapid, melodic, edges sharpened to laughter" contrasts beautifully with Ben's apologies "thick as custard." Their exchanges feel natural while advancing character development and plot. The narrative structure effectively builds tension through a series of escalating adventures, culminating in a satisfying yet open-ended conclusion. The introduction of Marco adds complexity to Alessandra's character and provides necessary context without overwhelming the central relationship. There are moments where the metaphorical language verges on purple prose ("The day folded into afternoon like a map refolding itself under capable hands"), but these instances are balanced by more straightforward narration. The writing maintains a consistent tone throughout, blending romantic tension with humor and cultural observations. The piece successfully incorporates all required elements from the prompt, including Alessandra's kleptomania, Ben's growing attraction, and their contrasting personalities. The narrative consists primarily of short scenes and dialogue exchanges as requested, and the word count is appropriate. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-executed romance that balances character development, setting, and narrative tension. It creates a complete arc while leaving room for the story to continue, exactly as requested in the prompt. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 86.3
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
They slide into the stool like a question mark—shoulders hunched, tentacles splayed in a careless crown. The bar lights catch the iridescence in their skin; the dreads clack against the brass footrail. Everyone else in the Outpost seems to breathe a little quieter. I keep my rag moving over the same slice of scarred counter because motion is a comfort and because motion tells me where the world ends and the wood begins. "Vega whisky, neat," they say. Quiet, clipped, like someone used to being listened to even when the room was full. "Better make that a double." I pour. The amber rolls into the glass like trapped sunlight. "You sure?" I ask more to buy time than to be careful. Oil stains in Asteroid Five's mining rigs can't be the only things to leave marks. They watch me pour like a lawyer watching a witness. "Certain." "Name?" Standard protocol, though out here names can be tokens or tools. People are forever leaving new ones on the table. They glance at the ceiling, counting whatever secrets are up there. "Kairo. K-E-I—never mind. Call me Kai." A wet laugh. "Or Nets, if you prefer—if you prefer the irony." I snort. "Touché." They tuck a tentacle under the collar where a pale scar shivers like a remembered frost. "You—you're Nets. Heard of you. Heard of this place." Their voice softens. "People say you keep...quiet. Keeps folks safer." I like that version of me. "Said by the ones with fewer scruples." I slide the glass across. It clinks. "First night?" Kai stares at the whisky like it might dissolve in sunlight. "No. Not first night. First time in three years, though." The hands—delicate, banded with silver—hover over the glass. "I don't want trouble, Nets." "Nobody wants trouble. Trouble likes you, though." I fold the rag. "You got somewhere to stay?" "The Outpost has rooms?" They almost sound surprised, as if the Outpost itself were a rumor told in better places. "I'll... pay." "It'll be a week at most, unless you have a chunk of ore to trade or a story I like." I point at the ledger by the tip tray. "Sign there. Name and credit." Kai slips a microchip across—old tech, probably swiped from some derelict. The chip pulses with a slow, guarded light. "Is that—legal?" "It's legal enough," I say. I don't ask where they got it. Sometimes asking is the sort of honesty that splits a life open. They sit a moment longer, then lower their voice. The Outpost hums around us: miners telling tall tales about veins of pure cobalt, a merchant bargaining for a crate of drought-resistant algae, two lovers arguing about whether "home" is a planet or a person. "Nets," Kai says, "I need information." I wipe the bar again—same spot, same rhythm. "That's the currency in this place." The rag leaves a darker ring where it's been rubbed thinner than the rest. "Information's free until it hurts." They laugh, but it doesn't reach their eyes. "I need to find someone. Name's Mira Sol. Been...missing. Possibly taken. I traced her ship's beacon to a transit relay in Sector Nine. The relay went dark right after. There were—eyes on it. Corporate eyes. Private eyes. Eyes that don't like to be seen." "That's a lot of eyes," I say, because it is. "And you think someone in here knows where the relay went dark? Or who saw it?" Kai looks like they swallowed glass. "I think someone traded that information. I think someone here might be the last one Mira spoke to." Across from us, a pair of miners drop a bar of something glinting and laugh too loud. A music box in the corner tries too hard to be cheerful. I keep my face easy. "You sure you're not chasing ghosts? Three years is a long silence." "They wouldn't—" Kai swallows. "Mira wouldn't vanish quietly. She sent me an encrypted image last moon. A red-orange glint. A face I didn't recognize. Then—nothing. Her last ping was from the relay. Weeks later their ship scraped into a salvage depot over in Keel Nine. Bodies recovered. Not hers." The cloth in my hand squeaks against the counter. "Correlation isn't conspiracy. Maybe she ran." "Kai's voice goes thin. "Mira wouldn't run. She was too stubborn. Too loyal. She’d rather get herself broken than let someone else get hurt." "Affection makes for a poor shield when you pick fights with companies," I say, but my voice is softer than I'd like. I know that loyalty. I used to have a version of it, once. It broke teeth. "That's why I need the relay logs," Kai says. "Not the public stuff—the private reroute packets. There's a trail if you know how to...read it." They lift a tentacle to gesture, and a wet smear of dark glints the rim of their sleeve. "I can pay." "How much?" Money here is a dose of diesel and a credit on the ledger. But information like that—private relay logs—cost more than credits. It costs reputation, favors, leverage. Kai's eyes flick up, sharp. "Enough to get you off this station for a night. Enough to make someone look twice before they call you a friend." I like the idea of leaving more than I like the thought of getting deeper. "Who else knows you came here?" "No one. I got here on a freighter out of Keel Nine. Came in low, paid in cash, kept to the shadows." They touch the glass, leave a crescent of condensation. "I crossed someone on the way in. Short. Missing an eye. Wore a patch with a company logo. He asked after Mira. He...smiled at me like I was a puzzle." I freeze on the rug of wiping. The bar seems to focus: the miners' laughter becomes static. The music box is a clock winding down. "Company logo, you say. Which one?" Kai hesitates. "I couldn't make it out. They spoke in clipped trade-speak. Took my microchip and asked if I was sending 'last messages.' I lied and said no." "Smart," I say. It isn't praise so much as an observation. "If they were looking for Mira, and that company had eyes on the relay, that means corporate level ops. Private sector with muscles and money. You realize that?" "I realize it's dangerous," Kai says, the words like stepping into cold water. "But I also realize the only other thing I can do is walk away." "Walking away is a strategy if you can stay away," I say. My rag moves faster, making a thin crescent of damp. "This Outpost is a hub. People come through. They hear things. Sometimes they talk. Sometimes talk rides back to where it matters." A woman at the end of the bar—a scout with a patch of white in her hair—tilts her head like she caught the tail of a conversation. Good instincts, that. Too many ears here. "You said this started three years ago," I tell Kai. "Why come now?" They pick up their glass and tilt it to the light like a jeweler appraising a stone. "I was hiding. Changed my face. New identity. But Mira's mother found the old data cache. She called me this week with a name. Said the last transmission was routed through a broker in Keel Nine. Said—" Kai's voice breaks. "—said if I didn't look, she would lose hope." "Hope's a dangerous commodity," I say. "It gets too expensive when companies sniff it out." Kai's tentacles curl, restless. "I have a contact in Keel Nine. A fixer. He owes me a favor. He can pull the relay logs if I can get him a seed file. I thought you might—" their look is direct for the first time, "—know who in the Outpost deals in old relay junk." I want to help. There's a reflex to it, like breathing. But my bed here is soft and thin, my debts knitted into the rafters by favors I've been trying to keep anonymous. "I know people who handle old hardware," I say slowly. "They don't ask many questions if you pay. But whoever’s watching that relay won't be a small-time salvage buyer. They paid big to keep it dark." Kai leans in. "Then I'll pay bigger." "No one pays bigger without strings," I say. "And I don't like strings." They close their eyes. The tentacles tremble. "I have nothing left but strings. Mira is—was my sister. Not by blood. By vow. I promised her I'd keep her safe." "Promises are warm things to die on," I counter. A laugh bubbles up, half-cynical. "Do you have a picture? Something concrete?" Kai brings a holo out from beneath their jacket, flicks it on. A young face blooms in the air: short hair, a crooked nose, eyes like a ship's horizon. I feel my stomach drop. I remember faces that have become echoes. "She's beautiful," I say, and the honesty tastes like rust. "She is," Kai says, and there’s a crack there now. "She's gone, Nets. Or she's been taken. I don't have much time." The Outpost ebbs around us, full of people whose tragedies are small enough to handle. Kai’s is a comet-size hurt that could take the place down if it hits the wrong way. I wipe the same spot on the counter until my fingers remember the grain. The rag's fibers catch on a splinter. A shadow passes across the doorway. For a second, a tall figure pauses—a coat with extra lining, a hat pulled low, the glint of a corporate insignia at the collar. My heart thuds, because shadows in this place rarely drift for nothing. Kai notices too. Their hand tightens on the glass until the ice clinks. "Stay," I say, because I am the Outpost and also because I am tired of the way leaving feels like neglect. They nod. "I'll be honest. I don't know who to trust." I nod back. "Good. Suspicion keeps you breathing longer than trust does." I slide the glass closer, then set my hand on top of theirs. The touch is a promise and also a warning. "We'll see who walks through that door. We’ll see who asks after you. And if anyone mentions Mira—" "I'll tell you," Kai whispers. "Good," I say. The bar door sighs; whatever walked by has moved on for now. The rag squeaks. The music box clatters on. Outside, an asteroid drifted into a richer sleep. But something larger is awake now. The corporate eyes. The missing woman. A fixer in Keel Nine. I keep wiping the same spot on the counter until the wood accepts the rhythm and my fingers stop trembling. We both wait, and the Outpost watches with us like a beast that knows someone has lit a match in the dark.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a cozy sci-fi atmosphere while establishing an intriguing conflict. The author has crafted a first-person, present-tense narrative as requested, with Nets as the bartender protagonist at The Last Outpost. The dialogue comprises roughly 60% of the text, meeting that requirement. The writing excels in establishing a distinct voice for Nets—world-weary, cautious, but with an underlying compassion. The prose creates a vivid sense of place through sensory details: the "iridescence in their skin," the whisky that "rolls into the glass like trapped sunlight," and the background ambiance of miners telling tales and merchants bargaining. Character development is strong. Nets reveals her character through her actions and observations rather than exposition. Kai is introduced as the mysterious stranger with "tentacled dreads askew" who needs help finding a missing person named Mira. Their desperation and determination come through clearly in both dialogue and subtle physical cues. The conflict is well-established: Kai is searching for Mira, who may have been taken by corporate interests, and needs Nets' help to access relay logs. The stakes are personal (Mira is Kai's sister "by vow") and potentially dangerous (corporate-level operations). The chapter ends without resolution, with the suggestion that someone may be watching them, creating tension that propels the reader forward. The dialogue is particularly strong—natural yet distinctive, revealing character and advancing plot simultaneously. Lines like "Hope's a dangerous commodity. It gets too expensive when companies sniff it out" efficiently convey both worldbuilding and Nets' perspective. The prose occasionally verges on purple but generally maintains a balance between evocative description and straightforward narration. Metaphors like "I keep my rag moving over the same slice of scarred counter because motion is a comfort and because motion tells me where the world ends and the wood begins" effectively convey Nets' state of mind. The pacing is well-controlled, with moments of tension interspersed with quieter character development. The chapter builds to a subtle climax with the appearance of a suspicious figure at the door, leaving the reader with questions about what will happen next. Some minor weaknesses include occasional overwriting and a few instances where the metaphors feel slightly forced. The worldbuilding, while atmospheric, could benefit from more concrete details about the asteroid belt setting. The conflict, while compelling, follows somewhat familiar lines for the genre. Overall, this is a strong piece of cozy sci-fi that establishes interesting characters and a compelling conflict while maintaining the requested tone and format. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 84.8
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The strap on my backpack keeps slipping off my shoulder like it’s trying to run away from me, too. Maybe I can't blame it. I’ve been running for twenty-four hours, give or take, and my feet have decided they are done pretending they can carry decisions this big. New Orleans smells like fried dough and diesel and something sweet I can't name, and I keep thinking if I turn the smell upside-down it will say, You made it. You’re allowed to stop because this is the part where everything fixes itself. It’s not that simple. The map in my head—escape route, exhale, start over—has been replaced by a rattled-up jumble of what-if’s and the sudden, loud possibility of being invisible in a city that doesn’t care. My phone battery is at twenty percent because I stole a charger off Mom’s nightstand before I left. It felt like stealing a part of the house that was still mine. I keep checking it anyway, like a teenager checking for likes, except I'm checking for evidence that I didn’t just wreck my life. I walk down Decatur because the map app says tourists go that way and tourists mean crowds and crowds mean anonymity. I need to vanish into a crowd long enough to think. The backpack strap slides, then slides again. I tuck it under my arm like a secret kid with a contraband. Every time it slips, my panic levels ping like cheap sonar. My hands are never still; if one isn't messing with the strap, it's picking at the fray of a seam on my jeans. Old habits. Old coping. I almost walk into a trash can when a voice says, “You okay, kid?” He’s about my age, maybe a year older, sprawled on the stoop of a shuttered cafe with two paper cups of coffee between his knees and a cigarette dangling like a beat-up flag. His hair is the kind that has been dyed three shades in and washed out to the exact color of disappointment. He’s got a tattoo peeking from the sleeve of his hoodie—some old sailor thing—and a nose ring that glistens when he smiles like he’s done too many things right to be sorry. Or maybe he’s doing the wrong things and is sorry. Hard to tell. I freeze, because everything in me has been trained to answer for everything. “I’m fine,” I lie. The word is a reflex, a small, useless weapon. He squints. “You look like you’ve run a marathon and lost,” he says. “Or that someone tried to yank your identity away and then did a messy half-ass job.” I want to tell him the whole thing at once: Tennessee, the counselor’s voice, Mom’s mouth opening like a cave I could fall into, the way Dad looked at me like I’d swapped their child for one that belonged to someone else. I want to say: I told them I’m Taylor and they tried to make me small. But the truth tastes like blood when I swallow it whole, so instead I say, “New to the city.” He laughs. “You and half the people who get off the bus.” He pats the stair between the coffee cups and waves me over like he’s inviting me into mischief. I sit because my legs forgot how to refuse a soft invitation. “Name’s Jules,” he says, extending a hand. My fingers are cold, and his handshake is warm enough to thaw something near my ribcage. “You got that luggage strap situation.” He nudges my shoulder. The strap slinks halfway off again. “Taylor.” My voice sounds like it came from a throat that hasn’t been used in months. I check reflexively—his eyes don’t linger on my chest. That’s a small mercy. “I’m—just… here.” “Running or visiting?” he asks. There’s a tilt to his head that reads like—are you drama or are you danger? “Running,” I say because it’s true. My mouth feels like the air around it is in permanent static. We share silence for a beat. The city buzzes. A brass band somewhere down the block plays a song that makes me want to cry for reasons I can’t name. Jules takes a sip of coffee and blows across the top like he’s cool, like he’s not exactly terrified of his future either. I think that and I like him a little more. “You’ll need food if you’re gonna run,” he says after a while. “Not that you don’t already know that. But I mean good food. Don’t waste your fifty bucks on beignets. Those are tourist bait.” “You can tell them apart?” I ask, surprised by my own laugh. “I’m terrible at tourist traps.” He grins. “Been here long enough to know the difference between a tourist and someone who belongs.” The word belongs hangs in the air like a dare. I laugh, because it hurts less than crying. “Where are you headed?” he asks and I almost say nowhere. Which is true and useless. What I want to say is, I don’t know how to be me out loud without it blowing up into something I didn’t sign up for. I want to say, I hope this city is big enough to swallow my secret and not spit it back at me. Instead I say, “I’m staying the night at a shelter.” The words feel like a tether thrown into a dark water. His face changes, a subtle folding like someone reading a new page. “Which one?” I give the name because it’s easier to say out loud than to lie. He nods like he expected as much. “Bad choice for first night,” he says. “Crowded. Cold. They’ll take you, but—” He shakes his head. “You got cash?” I blink. “Some.” “Come on,” Jules says. “I know a place. Cheap, warm, nobody asks too many questions. You look like you’ve been asked too many questions.” He puts out a hand like a lifeline. I want to check his pockets, his shoes, the way his eyes dart at every car that passes. Paranoia is practical now. But his hand is steady and his smile is frequented with honesty, which might be the stupidest reason to trust someone and also the only one I have. We walk. He tells me his story in bits—left a bad foster home in Baton Rouge, hopped buses, learned how to street-sleep without losing his mind, learned which churches give soup and which police will move you along. He talks like he’s been tracing his life with his finger on the map, like he’s been trying to find a place where the lines make sense. “You ever get scared?” I ask. The question is small but real. “Everyday,” he says. “But scared’s different than not surviving. You have to be scared to be smart. You can’t be reckless and live long out here.” “Noted.” I bump my shoulder against his because I like the small contact. The backpack strap slides off entirely and I yank it over. “I don’t know what I’m doing.” “Neither do I,” he says. “But we make do.” We find this place because it doesn’t look like a place a runaway should be able to find. It’s a laundromat by day and a diner by night, the owner’s daughter slinging burgers and smiling like nothing bad has ever happened in the world. The waitress—Leslie—squints when I come in, like she’s measuring me up. Maybe she’s trying to place me in the kind of trouble that walks in late. When Jules tells her it’s my first night in town, she softens. “First night’s on the house,” she says, tapping a tray. No one does that where I come from unless they’re angling for something, and yet she looks at me like she’s handing me a name tag I didn’t know I needed. We sit in a booth that smells faintly of bleach and fries, and I eat a burger like I’m inhaling a warm memory. My hands tremble while I take the first bite. Jules tells stories about the band he used to play in, about how the drum kit was too loud and he loved that it could be. He hums a tune under his breath and I almost cry because there’s something about someone making noise—music, words—that means they are trying to make their life continue instead of stop. The strap on my backpack slips again and I let it. Maybe I don’t have to fix everything right away. Maybe there’s a person named Jules who will teach me how to fix one thing at a time. Maybe, for now, surviving means letting someone else share the weight. Outside, the lights of Bourbon Street shimmer like a promise that’s probably a lie. I can hear laughter, loud and careless, and I feel both the pull to run back toward anything resembling home and the new, dangerous curiosity that keeps my feet planted. Jules watches me like he’s counting my breaths and timing them. “You can crash at mine,” he says, sudden and practical. “Not tonight. Just—if you want. My landlord’s an old drunk who thinks curtains are a luxury, but he doesn’t care who sleeps on the couch.” I think about shelters, about counselors' smugness, Mom’s voice clipped and sharp, about the way my name sounded like a question anymore. I imagine a couch that won’t hold me like a courtroom judge and I nod. “Yeah,” I say. “Okay.” He slides a cigarette my way and I decline. He shrugs and tucks it between his lips anyway, like old habits die slow. We step back into the air that smells like the river and a thousand stories. The strap on my backpack finally settles, maybe because I stopped fighting it. Maybe because I stopped trying to hold everything at once. I don’t know Jules well, not by any stretch. He could be a saint or a thief. He could be both. But for the first time in a long time, I don’t feel like the only person who knows what my haircut looks like at four in the morning. There’s a risk in trusting anyone, and I tuck that risk into my chest like a coin, heavy and precious. At some point tonight, I’ll have to text my mother. My thumb hovers over her contact like it's hot. I haven’t decided what I’ll say, haven't even decided if I’ll say anything. For now, I have a city, a burger, and a boy who knows how to move through trouble. The strap on my backpack settles, and for a moment that is as real as anything, I breathe.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a teenage runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans after coming out as trans and facing rejection. The first-person narration creates immediacy and intimacy, allowing readers to experience Taylor's disorientation, fear, and cautious hope. The prose has a distinctive style that feels authentic to a thoughtful, observant teenager. Lines like "New Orleans smells like fried dough and diesel and something sweet I can't name" and "his hair is the kind that has been dyed three shades in and washed out to the exact color of disappointment" demonstrate strong imagery and metaphorical thinking that reveals character without being overly sophisticated for a 16-year-old. The recurring motif of the slipping backpack strap works well as both a practical detail and a metaphor for Taylor's unstable situation. This subtle symbolism adds depth without being heavy-handed. The dialogue between Taylor and Jules feels natural and reveals character effectively. Their conversation has the tentative quality of two people sizing each other up while also recognizing something familiar in each other. The dialogue avoids exposition dumps while still conveying necessary information. The piece maintains emotional complexity throughout. Taylor experiences fear, uncertainty, and homesickness alongside moments of relief, connection, and cautious optimism. This emotional range prevents the character from feeling flat or the narrative from becoming monotonous. However, there are some weaknesses. The piece occasionally veers into slightly purple prose with metaphors that feel a bit forced, like "my mouth feels like the air around it is in permanent static." Some of the internal monologue becomes repetitive, particularly around Taylor's uncertainty and fear. The character of Jules, while interesting, borders on the "too-good-to-be-true" helper archetype. His immediate kindness and offer of shelter could have been balanced with more hints of his own complexities or struggles to make him feel more three-dimensional. The ending strikes a reasonable balance between acknowledging Taylor's ongoing challenges while offering a moment of respite and connection. It avoids both unrealistic optimism and gratuitous darkness, landing on a note of cautious hope that feels earned given the day's events. Overall, this is a strong piece that creates a believable character voice, establishes a vivid setting, and explores complex emotions while maintaining narrative momentum. The writing shows skill in balancing internal reflection with external action and dialogue. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17
