"Narrative coherence is for stories that can be edited. People die. People choke. People feel things. I provide clarity." "You sit on the boy and eat his breath," First Love said. "That's not clarifying." "Isn't it?" Mora arched a brow. "Max's body, tethered to his sleep, offers sustenance. He breathes, therefore he feeds me. I do a public service. I reduce waking overcrowding. Think of me as municipal." A murmur, like wind through reeds. Dream's impatience deepened; his cloak untucked just enough to reveal a hint of mischievousness. "Do you have permission?" Dream asked, deliberately slow. Mora cackled. It echoed up and down the vaulted ceiling and left the drips of light wobbling. "Permission is such a quaint thing. We, too, have needs. First Love sits there with his tidy little crescents and soft focus. He forgets—he cannot never forget—that longing is a hunger. Should it be starved?" First Love's cheeks flushed an almost-magical shade of crimson. "Consent was implicit. These scenes teach. They form patterns that a young mind will use." "And so do nightmares," Mora said. "I teach economy." Dream's grin was a tiny thing. He had once turned a whole village into a lesson on tax law for a particularly literal sleeper. He liked mischief; he liked precise, elegant mischief. He was tempted by a solution that would be educational for everyone. But there were rules. Or at least things that looked like rules when viewed from the right angle. "Max is twelve," said a voice from the gallery. It belonged to a rumor, which had to be legally sworn in. "He keeps waking with bruises on his ribs and an inexplicable fondness for late Gothic literature." "Objection: relevance," said Dream, promptly overruling himself. Later, he would claim this was merely rhetorical. Now he sighed, which was a small raincloud. Mora's defense lawyer—an actual lawyer made of soot and bureaucracy—produced a list of exigencies, cited Middle Syllabus Clause 4: Nocturnal Foraging, and submitted photo evidence: a set of breath-stripped air with a polite label. It looked like a respectable still life. Then Mora herself offered, almost shyly, the core of her defense. "A girl's gotta eat too, you know?" she repeated, as if delivering a line she'd practiced and only now found its proper weight. First Love flinched as if struck. The court's florists leaned forward. Dream let a millisecond of laughter escape and closed it quickly, like a curtain. "That is not a legal argument," First Love said, though he could not help the tremble in his voice, which gave it a curiously stirring quality. "It is practical," Mora said. "Ought we legislate compassion? There are nightmares who died last winter. Their families—other nightmares—lack closure, and closure is expensive." She tapped her shawl where the cold was thinnest. "Also, personally: I've never been satisfied with those teenage kisses. The choreography is so...predictable." "It is literally a metaphor for first love," First Love said. "Metaphors are not edible." "Everything is edible if you twist it long enough," Mora said. She leaned forward, and for an instant the boy in the filed—Max—shifted in his seat. In the dream's daytime, the girl's laughter morphed into the moist glint of teeth. Max woke a little. "That is not how ownership works," Dream said. He had the patience of tides but the humor of someone who kept a rubber duck for emergencies. "We balance influence. We weigh intention against impact." "What about the boy?" First Love pleaded. "He—" "—woke up once with a poem he didn't remember writing," Dream supplied. "And once with the sudden ability to pronounce 'Mendeleev' correctly." He looked at Mora. "And with your modifications, he woke with bruises. We are not heartless." Mora folded her hands. "He also woke with—" She paused, searching the crowded throng for a phrase that might make sense. "Complexity." First Love's tears gleamed like varnish. "It's formative, not formative in that way." Dream considered the several possible rulings. Exile Mora to the Blank Places? Fine, but nightmares prefer exile like fish prefer dry bowls. Order reparations? Not a terrible idea, but who pays who? Assign joint custody of the field? That sounded like a disaster: custody agreements in the Dreaming typically involve paint, unresolved Oedipus references, or both. Then the mischief arrived, a warm, small thing behind Dream's eyes. He liked mischief that taught people something about themselves, like a sugar-free candy. "Very well," Dream said, voice sliding like a curtain. "We shall try restorative measures." Mora blinked, genuinely interested. "Restorative?" "You will share the dream," Dream said. "Not simultaneously." He allowed a craftful smile to play at the edges of his sentence. "You will alternate nights. On Mora nights, you may—discreetly—perform your foraging; on First Love nights, you will be absent. Additionally, Mora, you will join First Love in an apprenticeship of soft focus and accidental blushes for one lunar cycle. First Love will teach you choreography. First Love, you will learn how hunger informs longing. Both of you will appear, in Max's waking life, as two smaller, less obvious promptings: one that makes him write slightly better poems, the other that makes him put garlic on his toast—" "Garlic?" a chorus of dreams asked. "It keeps nightmares polite," Dream said, deadpan. "Also, consider it a minor dietary amendment." Mora's cackle, muffled, still found its way into the rafters. "You mean, we have to—what? Share recipes?" "Not recipes," Dream said. "Boundaries." He toyed with a small, glinting idea. "If any party breaks the agreement, I will rearrange Max's recurring scenes into a judicial simulation: a nightmare in which he's ten students wearing identical faces and the entire school is an appeals court." That got a gasp. Nightmares do not enjoy paperwork. Mora smiled, but there was the faintest retracting of claws. "An appeals court where he is also the janitor," she added, diplomatic. First Love sniffed. "Fine. But—" "And one more condition," Dream interjected. "Mora, you may not—under any circumstances—assume the girl's form in such…specific alignment with the pillow." He said the last word as if it were a burglary tool. Mora's cackle turned into a laugh that was almost a concession. "Fine. I will sit in a chair. Or on his ankle. There are other options." "Good," Dream said. "Case adjourned. Mediate your feelings. Feed your appetites elsewhere. Remember, the Dreaming is not a vacuum; it's a negotiation." As the court dissolved into the soft skitter of bureaucrats adjusting their papers and the brittle snicker of old jokes, Dream lingered. He could have sent Mora to the Harvests, or assigned Max a recurring dream of accountants as vigilantes. Instead he chose the small cruelty that taught: alternating nights would make the field richer, because oppositions sharpen images. He was fond of ironies. Outside, Max turned in his bed. The wildflowers inched closer; the girl's laugh softened. Mora left a faint scent of winter on the hem of the dream, and First Love tucked a ribbon behind a pixel of hair. They would learn to be tolerable company for one another. The court would file its docket under "relational remedies." Mora rose, gathered her shawl, and gave the court a little bow that might have been gratitude or a prelude. Her cackles echoed once more, cheerfully off-key, as if thinking about supper. Dream watched her go and permitted himself the tiniest of pranks: a ripple in the field that made one of the wildflowers grow a tiny, judicial wig. The plant looked appropriately officious, and for a moment everyone in the room considered the dignity of flowers. Then the court returned to order, because even mischief had a timetable. Outside, the sleepers turned; a boy in a bed smiled, or perhaps grimaced, and somewhere in his chest something rearranged itself into a new, awkward shape that would, over the years, make a decent poem.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a dark fantasy courtroom scene with comedic elements as requested. The author has crafted a world where dreams are tangible entities with legal standing, and nightmare spirits can be brought to court for territorial disputes. The writing excels in establishing the Court of the Dreaming with evocative imagery that feels appropriately dreamlike: "a bench of cloud-wrought marble that never quite settled beneath the weight of its own edicts" and light "the color of old coins and rain on a tin roof." These descriptions are economical yet effective, setting the scene without overwhelming exposition. Dream is portrayed with the requested irritation at having to adjudicate such matters, shown through his "impatience like a heavy cloak" and the clicking of his teeth. The characterization of First Love as "small, round-cheeked" with a practiced blush contrasts effectively with Mora, wrapped in "a shawl of cold that rustled like moth wings" with hair in "wet coils that caught the courtlight and held it like secrets." The comedy derives naturally from the absurdity of the situation—a nightmare spirit and a romantic dream entity arguing over territorial rights—and the courtroom drama elements transplanted into this fantastical setting. The humor is indeed dark and understated, particularly in lines like Mora's repeated defense that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" and Dream's deadpan explanation that garlic "keeps nightmares polite." The dialogue flows naturally and reveals character, particularly in the exchanges between First Love and Mora. Their arguments about consent, hunger, and the purpose of dreams add depth to what could have been one-dimensional characters. The resolution shows Dream's mischievous side as requested, with his solution forcing both parties to learn from each other while maintaining the integrity of Max's dreamscape. The ending avoids being too neat or saccharine, maintaining the dark undertone while suggesting growth for all involved. There are a few instances where the prose becomes slightly purple, with metaphors that call attention to themselves rather than serving the narrative. For example, "Dream's impatience deepened; his cloak untucked just enough to reveal a hint of mischievousness" feels a bit forced as imagery. The piece occasionally meanders, particularly in the middle section where the legal arguments become somewhat repetitive. Some tightening of the exchanges between First Love and Mora would have maintained momentum better. Overall, this is a strong response that successfully balances dark fantasy with comedy, creates a unique dreamlike courtroom, and resolves the conflict with appropriate mischief from Dream. The writing is engaging, the characters distinct, and the world-building effective without overwhelming the narrative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Blood Moon — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Blood Moon Alucard & Yennefer Write a story where Alucard (Hellsing) encounters Yennefer (The Witcher) in medieval Europe. Yennefer's magical abilities intrigue the vampire, while she's both repulsed and fascinated by his monstrous nature. Their power dynamic shifts constantly as they circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first. **Alucard (Hellsing)** Alucard is an ancient, immensely powerful vampire who works for the Hellsing Organization. He can regenerate from almost any wound and shape-shift at will. He's sadistic, arrogant, and takes pleasure in toying with his enemies before killing them. Despite being a monster, he despises weak vampires who can't accept their nature. He wears a distinctive red coat, wide-brimmed hat, and orange sunglasses. He uses massive handguns loaded with silver bullets. He seeks worthy opponents who can challenge him and potentially end his immortal existence. Famous quote: "The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame." **Yennefer of Vengerberg (The Witcher)** Yennefer is a powerful sorceress who magically altered her appearance to hide her congenital hunchback. She's ambitious, stubborn, and manipulative when necessary. She has violet eyes and smells of lilac and gooseberries. Despite her cold exterior, she desperately wants to reverse her infertility caused by magical transformation. She's centuries old but appears young. She's politically savvy and refuses to be underestimated. She has a sarcastic sense of humor and little patience for fools. Though she rarely shows it, she's capable of deep love and loyalty. Famous quote: "I'm not sweet and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A crimson harvest moon hangs like a burnished coin above the thatch and timber of the empty village, flooding the narrow lanes with blood-tinted light. The air is thin, sharp with frost, and carries the far-off scent of woodsmoke and rot. Crows have fallen silent; only the whisper of wind moves through the eaves. Under that unnatural luminescence a figure in a red coat moves like a cut of shadow—tall, deliberate, absurdly still. Alucard pauses at the edge of the square, hat tipped low, the orange lenses of his glasses catching moonlight like twin embers. The handguns at his hips glint silver; their barrels are impossibly large and absurdly ornate, as if designed by a mad jeweler. He inhales. The night tastes of fear, old blood, and something else—an undercurrent of power that pricks like a shard of ice along his nerves. He smiles, which is to say his teeth show; it is always a smile that is both invitation and promise. She is not where she should be, not expected on these damp cobbles where peasants bury their dead and wolves come to gossip. Yennefer moves with the surety of someone used to inhabiting rooms that ripple with ley lines and court intrigue. Her silhouette is slender beneath dark robes, a black ribbon at her throat and hair bound back to accent the planes of a face that has been reshaped to the precise geometry of beauty. The violet of her eyes gleams, almost too bright under the red moon, and when she turns her head she smells of lilac and gooseberries as clearly as if a garden followed her. They see each other across an empty well. The world holds its breath. Alucard steps forward, the sound of boot on stone soft but distinct. He delights in theatrics; every tilt of his hat is deliberate, every measured approach a small performance. "A sorceress under a blood moon," he muses, voice like silk over glass. "How very convenient." Yennefer’s mouth curves—almost, but not quite, amusement. She meets his smile with a shield of disdain. There is a wariness in her posture, one born of a lifetime of duels with men who thought magic made them clever. Her fingers rest against the small chain at her throat, not in supplication but as if to remind herself of the anchor between skin and bone. "And a vampire," she replies. "How quaint. The Hellsing emblem? You don't look like a hooligan, monsieur. You look… theatrical." "Names are a courtesy worn thin." Alucard's laughter is soft, indulgent. "Alucard. I hear a great many things in the dark. The Witcher courts have tales of a sorceress who treaded into regions where men bring lanterns to find their courage. I find it dull to listen to the wind speak when the wind brings company." Yennefer’s violet eyes narrow. She does not correct him that she is no witcher; that she need not tread where men take lanterns. She knows him by reputation as well—tales travel in odd directions: the monster who hunts his own kind, who delights in the theater of death. That reputation fits him too well. Her pulse is steady. "You're far from London, Alucard. You don't belong in a place like this unless you're looking for something." "A hunt always seeks." He swivels, a slow, deliberate arc, drinking in the abandoned houses, the shuttered window with a child's handprint faded on the glass. "But tonight the hunt is entertained. The moon is generous." Yennefer's mouth tightens. The generosity of the moon is a danger she understands. Sorcery bears its own costs—beautiful, perilous bargains—and she has spent lifetimes balancing them. She lifts her chin. "Then hunt. Or dance. I have little patience for theatrics." They circle. Each step is a logistical map: measure, countermeasure, the architecture of intention. Alucard's amusement is visible in the slight cock of his head; Yennefer's disdain is a fortress with copper-sheathed towers. Their power dynamic is not simple predator-prey. It folds and unfolds with every small assessment. She knows, as all students of magic learn, how fragile control can be. He knows, as an immortal creature who devours legends, how quickly admiration curdles to contempt. He admires her. A sorceress who hides scars and alters bone takes a certain kind of courage. "Your magic," he says, taste in his voice, "it smells like secrets and sea. Lilac and an ocean that keeps trying to drown itself." She blinks at the oddity of his phrasing, then lifts a shoulder. "It smells like exhaustion and practice. What of your blood, vampire? It smells of iron and arrogance." His grin widens until the edges of that grin make her think of carved marble. "And you—how brave you are to name it." Words are gestures here, both trying to pluck at an opponent's slack. Yennefer answers with silence, then, with a flick of her wrist, draws glyphs in the air. The marks glow a sickly, opaline color, hurried lines braided with runic loops. Alucard leans forward, attentive—not in fear, but in curiosity. The design is reckless, beautiful. It sings of unspent fury. She feels him watching, and something like a thrill spirals through her, a dangerous one. His attention is a vice. She invokes, voice low, syllables gaining weight as the moon climbs. The earth at her feet darkens; frost lifts in a ring. Snowflakes rise like shivered glass shards around them and do not fall. The stage tilts. Alucard applauds, the sound dry as paper. "Neat trick. You bind winter to silence and make the cold your sentinel. I approve." "You approve a thing you find useful?" She is amused now. For all her disdain, she has a hunger in her, an intellectual amusement at a creature who appreciates craft. "You flatter badly." He appreciates it because it is an art, a signature. He sees weakness where others see suffering—weakness of denial—but he sees strength in someone who took a crooked future and straightened it with sorcery until bone obeyed. He moves as if to test the frost, but the air shifts—an invisible barrier, not rough enough to stop his stride but enough to slow it. Alucard's amusement deepens into the relish of a challenge. He does not waste a weapon; he unfolds instead, a ripple across flesh and shadow. His form elongates, a smear of black silk and teeth briefly visible where his grin had been. He could be a hundred things and chooses to remain near his human shape; he likes the theatricality too much to vanish into pure horror. They trade jabs—witty, barbed, and layered with threat. Yennefer hurls a flare of light; he answers with a wave that bends that light into a swarm of night-moths that explode into embers and fall harmlessly away, doesn't shatter but toys with it. He does not burn. He toys. His hands move like a conductor's. For the first time the balance shifts. Yennefer's eyes flash violet, her voice hissing the note of command older than a village's memory. She drives a thorn of ice at him, a spear of frozen thought meant to pierce the skin of immortality. It bites, an arrogant sting, but Alucard's skin ripples, a sea recollecting a storm. The spear dissolves as if fed to a hungry tide. He laughs—laughs aloud, a sound that seems to drink the cold. "Predictable," he croons. "You put too much of yourself into the throw." Her hands twirl in the air, and the snow rises, forming a diadem of blades around her. She will not be trifled with. Yet her voice loses a fraction of steel: she is tempted, and it shows as a vulnerability. She would like to measure him, to take him apart and study the mechanism behind the myth—see if there is a single seam through which death might slip. In private, she dreams of making bargains that end suffering. This man both tempts and repels. He perceives that yearning. Alucard's eyes glint with something like hunger that is not solely for blood. "You want to mend what the world broke," he says softly. "You bind, you twist yourself to fit beauty and function. How quaint." She bristles. "I made a choice. I paid for it. Do not talk to me of quaintness." "You are so fierce to deny what you are," he says. "And yet, here you are—centuries old, seeking to reverse one small thing. I admire that. The vanity of it is delicious." She steps closer. Up close he is all contradictions: cold and intoxicating, ancient and amused. Closer still, Yennefer smells older things—the iron tang of old graves, the metallic dryness of a chalice that has seen a hundred rituals. His eyes bore into hers, not seeking dominance so much as invitation. A challenge wrapped in velvet. Their dance continues, neither willing to be the first to drop mask or weapon. For all their power, neither draws the killing edge. They trade truths like blows, each careful not to break the other's jaw. A vampire can always eat the sorceress, but he seeks something he cannot easily swallow: a mind that will not yield, a soul that resists the finality of his fangs. A sorceress can lay wards and condemnations, but she wonders if there's a way to fix a thing whose wounds are immortal. Moonlight paints them in red and black. Around the edges of the square, the night waits. Alucard tilts his head, the smile widening into something almost fond. "We will not end tonight," he says. "This village will sleep another night. But I will remember you, Yennefer. Remember—if you ever want to be tested properly, call for me. Or do not. I am not in the habit of pressing." Yennefer's eyes narrow, measuring the sincerity behind the mockery. She will not invite him, and she will not close the door he leaves ajar. "I don't call anyone," she replies. "Least of all monsters with a taste for dramatics." Alucard bows, ridiculously, with exaggerated flourish. "Then consider this a hand left unbroken. We may cross paths in other centuries." She turns, the fog of frost parting at her heels, dignity reclaiming her shoulders. For a heartbeat—no more—she allows herself to meet his gaze without armor. In it she sees not merely the monster but a tired, arrogant spark chasing a satisfying end. She does not pity him. She does not offer mercy. "Good night, Alucard," she says. "I am not your entertainment." "No," he agrees, voice a caress and a threat. "You are not. You are… interesting." They withdraw into opposite shadows, the red moon swallowing their forms like ink. The village exhales. Somewhere a crow begins to croak again. The frost settles. Neither has bared enough teeth to claim the night. The balance holds, precarious and exquisite, as if the very moon were the blade between them—red, bright, and hungry.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a tense, atmospheric encounter between Alucard and Yennefer, capturing both characters' essences while maintaining a consistent tone throughout. The author demonstrates a strong command of language, creating vivid imagery that establishes the medieval setting and supernatural elements effectively. The characterization is particularly strong. Alucard's theatrical nature, arrogance, and fascination with worthy opponents comes through clearly in his dialogue and actions. His vampiric nature is conveyed through sensory descriptions and his fluid, unsettling movements. Yennefer is equally well-portrayed—her magical abilities, pride, and complex motivations are all present. The author captures her disdain, intelligence, and the vulnerability she tries to hide. The power dynamic between the characters shifts subtly throughout their encounter, with neither willing to show weakness first, exactly as requested. Their circling is both literal and metaphorical, creating tension that sustains throughout the piece. The dialogue is particularly strong, revealing character while advancing the narrative. Each character speaks in a distinctive voice that feels true to their established personalities. The prose is elegant and atmospheric, though occasionally it veers into purple territory with overly ornate descriptions. Some sentences are unnecessarily complex, which can momentarily pull the reader out of the otherwise immersive experience. For example, "Their power dynamic is not simple predator-prey. It folds and unfolds with every small assessment" is followed by more explanation that feels somewhat overwrought. The imagery is consistently strong, with sensory details that create a vivid picture: "A crimson harvest moon hangs like a burnished coin above the thatch and timber of the empty village, flooding the narrow lanes with blood-tinted light." The author effectively uses the blood moon as both setting and metaphor throughout. The story maintains coherence despite its complex subject matter. The narrative flows logically from the initial meeting through their verbal and magical sparring to their parting, with neither character gaining a decisive advantage. This aligns perfectly with the prompt's request for a constantly shifting power dynamic. The ending avoids resolution, maintaining the tension established throughout. This works well for the encounter described—these are two powerful, cautious beings sizing each other up, neither willing to commit fully to either alliance or enmity. Overall, this is a sophisticated piece that demonstrates strong character work, atmospheric writing, and an understanding of how to create and maintain tension. Its few weaknesses lie in occasional overwriting and some unnecessarily complex sentence structures. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 81.8
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A dim overhead light flickers in the prison corridor at irregular intervals, throwing long, jittering shadows across the peeling linoleum. The air tastes of disinfectant and metal; far-off, the clang of a rolling door punctuates the silence like a metronome for people who have forgotten what time is. Jolyne Cujoh shoulders the weight of a prison-issued duffel and the thicker weight of suspicion. Her butterfly tattoo peeks from beneath the cuff of a denim vest. She moves with coiled muscle and hard eyes, braid-buns perched like twin warning signs. Every step is a promise she can unspool herself and strike like a wire. She came prepared to hate everyone. A frame for murder, a life ripped out from under her, an institution full of men who think their jokes cut deeper than any blade — the usual. But this place hums differently, and when she walks past Cell Block C she feels it like a string plucked against a raw nerve. People glance up from their cots with the same guarded reverence one reserves for a guard with a gun, or a nightmare. When a woman in a crisp gray coat appears under the flickering light by the administration door, Jolyne registers the incongruity before her eyes process it. The coat is too clean. The smile is too soft. The auburn hair is pinned like a ribbon around her face, and those yellow eyes — ringed like a predator’s — regard the corridor as if it belongs to her. "You're the new arrival." Her voice is all rounded edges and sugar. "Makima." She inclines her head lightly, the kind of tiny gesture designed to put people at ease. It works on most people. Not on Jolyne. Jolyne stops a measuring breath away. "Yeah?" She keeps her voice low, low enough that no overhearing ears can catch the cadence of challenge in it. Stone Free hums at the edges of her perception — always there, coiled like thread around bones. "Name's Cujoh. Jolyne. What's it to you?" Makima's smile doesn't twitch. Her lashes flutter like a curtain. "Just making sure everybody is welcomed." Her hand lifts, palm outward in a placating ironclad gesture. "This facility has...special needs. We help people adjust." The last word hangs. Jolyne knows manipulative phrases when she hears them. They come in soft rain or a velvet glove around a fist. "Special needs, huh?" She rolls her shoulders. "You mean like torturing people with sugar?" "You've been through a lot," Makima says, and her eyes move over Jolyne's arms, the tattoo, the posture. "It takes strength to arrive without breaking." The compliment is exactly the wrong kind — heavy as honey, sticky with intent. Jolyne eyes her. A thread twitches beneath her skin, restless. She decides to test the sugar. No one softens her with flattery unless they want to wear her like a collar. "So, what does the Control Devil do for fun?" Jolyne asks, loud enough that a guard making his rounds narrows his eyes. "Walk around and collect pets?" Makima murmurs, as if amused at the idea of a pet: "I prefer the term...caretaker." Her tone is almost conspiratorial. "Pets require boundaries, love, and guidance. I provide that to those who need structure." The guard glances over but doesn't step in. He probably thinks two women arguing is theatre. He wouldn't survive long in either of their jokes. "Don't like being told 'need' by people who make 'need' for a living," Jolyne says. "I've seen guys do that before. Make you think you're nothing without 'em." Her fingers brush her arm where the butterfly sits. "I don't bow to owners." Makima's gaze narrows, tiny, dangerous. "Do you bow to the one you love?" Jolyne's face burns. It's a trap — personal, cheap. Her father’s voice flickers in her head: keep your cool. Stone Free recoils, the strings whispering like a warning. She takes a breath, follows it, uses it. "Don't know what you're talking about. Don't try me." "Good." The smile becomes a practiced expression of sympathy. "People who don't test their limits usually end up safe. But safe isn't always best, is it?" "Who are you really talking to?" Jolyne asks. The corridor seems to tighten. Somewhere a light blinks slower, like someone holding their breath. "You like playing puppeteer, huh? You got leashes." Makima leans forward a fraction. "Everyone wants someone to care for them. Even the strongest sometimes crave direction. You must understand that better than most." Her eyes glint, measuring. "Your Stand—Stone Free, isn't it? Fascinating. To unravel, to be both body and string." Blood hammers in Jolyne's ears. That name leaves sensations like an electric shock. She hates being looked at like a specimen. "Who told you 'bout that? I don't spill names to bureaucrats." Makima's smile doesn't drop. "Information flows in unexpected currents in a place like this." She tilts her head. "It would be a tragedy if someone with such a rare ability were left misunderstood." Jolyne can smell the bait now. It reeks of 'we can help you' and 'I can make things easier' and the way people like Makima promise ladders down into quicksand. She tries to unspool her anger — threads whispering, waiting for the right flick. "Ain't you the one who keeps folks on leashes and calls it care? You into the whole ownership vibe?" She makes a chain-clicking motion with her fingers, mocking. Makima’s smile finally fractures, just enough to show teeth. "Dogs are supposed to die for their owners," she says softly, almost reverently. For a moment the corridor is stripped of pretense. The words sit there, cold and clean. Jolyne feels them like a slap. "Jesus, that's messed up." Jolyne laughs, too loud, chest burning. "You mean you get off on being god? You want to own people so bad you'd—" "Not everyone can handle the truth about themselves," Makima interrupts. Her voice is velvet; the steel beneath is only for moments like this. "I give people purpose. And in exchange, they give me their obedience." The word "obedience" makes Jolyne’s skin crawl. Stone Free hums, coiling ready. She could lash out and let string bite into the soft tissue of that smile. But something more dangerous moves in Makima's eyes than the typical bully. There is a predator calibration — the sort that counts outcomes, that can turn an ally into a weapon with a whisper. "Why you so interested in my Stand?" Jolyne asks instead. "You want to leash me? Tie me up and call it structure?" Makima's expression becomes almost tender. "I like control. But I like power structured with understanding. You have an ability to become both one thing and many things. That's...useful." The word useful carries a weight of possession that makes Jolyne's muscles tighten. "I prefer partnership to dragging things by force. Mutual benefit makes the bond stronger." "Mutual," Jolyne echoes, tasting the lie. "Yeah? So what do you want from me, exactly? My compliance? My strings?" Makima moves closer, five inches of measured diplomacy. Her ringed eyes bore into Jolyne's, and for the first time the prison's flicker seems to slow to a drip. "I want to know what you'd do if everything you needed was taken away. I want to see how you rebuild." She smiles. "If you accept discipline, you can get what you want. Family, justice...freedom." "Too many promises in one neat little bow," Jolyne says. "You offering fairy dust now?" Makima's hand reaches out, not touching, merely framing Jolyne's cheek in air. Her fingertips hover an inch away, and Jolyne feels an itch as though a string brushes her skin. "I can help you find Chainsaw Man," she whispers. "Or at least, I can help you find what you think you want most." The name lands like an anvil. Jolyne knows Chainsaw Man — the idea of him ripples through Makima like oxygen. A trap is obvious now: the promise of something sacred used to twist someone into servitude. Jolyne's gut clenches. Her father would have snarled at being toyed with. She will not be toyed with. "Keep your leash," she spits. Stone Free wakes properly then, threads growing faintly visible at the edges of her arms like a shimmer. They answer first in instincts, pulsing hot at her fingers. "I ain't handing my strings to puppeteers." Something sharp passes over Makima's face for a heartbeat — amused, impressed, maybe disappointed. She inclines her head with actual approval. "You are spirited," she says. "A quality I respect." "Respect don't mean you get to own me," Jolyne retorts, and then, because she can’t help it, she grins hard. "If you think you can make me your dog, you've got another thing coming." "Then stay free," Makima says, and though the words are soft, they land like a verdict. "But be careful: Freedom can be lonely. Many choose direction eventually." Jolyne tugs her duffel strap higher and starts to walk, Stone Free threading the air behind her like a banner. The string feels alive against her skin — protectively taut. Every cell in her smarted with the knowledge of how dangerous a soft voice can be. Makima watches her retreat, expression unreadable. Down the corridor, as Jolyne moves into shadow, Makima's eyes flick toward the guard now passing the administrative door. For a blink — a heartbeat — her hand disappears into her coat and emerges with a small paperclip, cheap and metallic. She drops it into a pocket like a seed planted for later. Her smile returns, complete and serene, and she murmurs to herself in a tone made only for prayers or manipulation: "We shall see which binds first." Jolyne's footsteps recede, the strings of Stone Free whispering behind her. She doesn't trust the woman who calls herself a caretaker. The more she learns about men who control, the harder she fights. Makima's web of polite phrases and promises will not hold her — not if her strings have anything to say about it. But in the flickering light, the prison itself seems to listen. Two forces orbit one another now: one made of iron and resolve, the other of velvet and coercion. Both understand what the other could do. Neither has yet shown their full hand. The corridor keeps the secret for a while longer, humming under the pulse of their tension like a wire stretched tight between two poles.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures a tense first encounter between Jolyne Cujoh and Makima in a supernatural prison setting. The author demonstrates strong understanding of both characters, portraying Jolyne's defiant, hot-headed nature and Makima's manipulative, falsely sweet demeanor with accuracy to their source materials. The prose is generally strong, with effective imagery establishing the prison atmosphere through sensory details like the "flickering light" and air that "tastes of disinfectant and metal." The author skillfully uses these environmental elements to enhance the psychological tension between the characters. Character portrayal is particularly strong. Jolyne's internal thoughts reveal her suspicion and resistance to manipulation, while Makima's calculated responses and subtle threats maintain her canonical personality. The dialogue exchanges effectively showcase their battle of wits, with Makima probing for weaknesses and Jolyne refusing to submit. The writing maintains consistent third-person present tense as requested, and the length appears appropriate. The author incorporates key character traits like Jolyne's Stand ability and Makima's control powers naturally into the narrative. However, there are some weaknesses. Occasionally, the prose becomes slightly purple, with metaphors that feel somewhat forced ("her voice is all rounded edges and sugar"). Some dialogue exchanges could be tightened for greater impact. The narrative sometimes tells rather than shows, particularly when explaining Makima's manipulative nature rather than letting it emerge purely through her actions. The ending effectively establishes ongoing tension between the characters without resolution, appropriate for a first encounter. The final image of "a wire stretched tight between two poles" aptly captures their standoff. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully brings together characters from different universes in a believable confrontation that honors their established personalities and abilities. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 85.7
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-████ Object Class: Euclid Special Containment Procedures: SCP-████ is the designation given to the phenomenon affecting Dr. Elias Rowan (formerly Researcher Elias Rowan), currently assigned to Site-17, Department of Temporal Studies. Dr. Rowan is to remain under Level-3 observation while residing in a secure residential wing. All standard-issue Foundation memo pads and any paper matching Foundation memo specifications are to be catalogued and stored in a locked evidence locker (Locker 17-T). Access to writing implements is restricted; only authorized personnel may issue restricted stationery following approval from the Site Director and a temporal-security officer. Any newly discovered instances of handwritten notes on Foundation memo paper are to be logged as SCP-████-instances and transferred to Containment Archives following decontamination protocols for information hazards. If an SCP-████-instance contains actionable temporal parameters or directives, Mobile Task Force Pi-7 ("Calendars") will be notified immediately and will follow preapproved temporal intervention protocols. Psychological evaluation of Dr. Rowan will continue biweekly; any signs of acute dissociation or memetic influence will trigger immediate memetic countermeasures. Description: SCP-████ refers to a series of handwritten notes that appeared to have been penned by Dr. Elias Rowan and delivered to him at irregular intervals. All notes were written on standard Foundation memo paper and in a handwriting conclusively matched to Dr. Rowan's by Graphology Unit-4. The anomalous property is that the notes were received prior to or in the absence of any outward means of delivery, and their content predicts or warns of an imminent containment breach involving a presently contained entity (see Addendum ███-A). Some notes included details that were later corroborated; others contained information that contradicted recorded events or basic physical facts. Dr. Rowan reported the first note on 02/14/20██. At the time he was a junior temporal analyst assigned to temporal anomaly research. He presented the note to his supervisor, believing it a prank. The note read: [Begin SCP-████-01] Eli, Lock the east lab door tonight at 23:00. Do not, under any circumstances, let her near the chrono-core. She will ask about "the light." Say nothing. —E. [End SCP-████-01] Dr. Rowan followed the instruction and nothing observable happened that night. The memo was filed. Subsequent notes, however, increased in frequency and urgency. Notes were always composed in ballpoint ink on Foundation-issued memo paper, even when Dr. Rowan kept all such paper in a locked drawer. Physical attempts to intercept delivery (security sweeps, CCTV review, electromagnetic scans) returned null results for ingress or tampering. The notes could not be explained by standard memetic vectors: they contained no anomalous script, were not digitally reproduced, and bore normal ink signatures consistent with Dr. Rowan's personal pressure patterns. The psychological component is significant. Dr. Rowan's testimony indicates progressive erosion of trust in his perceptions. He reported waking and finding notes in places he'd previously searched and re-locked; at times he wrote replies in the margins and found them unchanged in later copies. His insistence that the notes were from his "future self" led to procedural conflicts with temporal containment protocols. Addendum ███-B — Selected Notes (transcribed, verbatim) Notes are reproduced in the original tense, punctuation, and line breaks. Each item is preceded by the date Dr. Rowan reported discovery. 03/01/20██ — SCP-████-03 [Begin] Elias, Do not take the train on Tuesday. The corridor will tilt. If you think of the child in the corridor, stop. Call Oppen. He will lie. —E. [End] 03/17/20██ — SCP-████-07 [Begin] Eli, She knows your name now. Do not tell her which memory is yours. The lab will taste like pennies. Burn the list if you find it. The list is not a list. —E. [End] 04/02/20██ — SCP-████-12 [Begin] Elias, The breach is not a bruise. It is a notched clock. If you correct the notch with the silver key, you will fold the wrong day over. Give her the stopwatch. Say "Before." Do not look at the mirrors during transition. —E. [End] 05/10/20██ — SCP-████-18 (heavily smudged) [Begin] Eli, I am sorry. I tried to staple the hours but they slipped. The cameras remember only what is allowed. Remember the melon. Remember the number sixteen. If anyone asks, you were never in 2016. —E. [End] 06/04/20██ — SCP-████-27 (ink frantic; letters breaking) [Begin] Eli, You closed the door but it is still open. The girl smiles because she is the only one who remembers the color of the lab coat. We could have stopped it at three. Do not trust the three easy men. Hide your hands. Hide them from the glass. I am not asking anymore. —E. [End] 06/13/20██ — SCP-████-31 (postmarked with Foundation internal stamp; impossible) [Begin] Elias, I wrote this and then I un-wrote it. If you fold the paper twice and hold it to the light the seam will show the wrong year. Do not perform the recalibration on 06/21. If you believe you must, cut the left cable not the right. She is the right cable. —E. [End] Notes later in the series became increasingly incoherent and occasionally contained assertions contradicting recorded reality (e.g., statements that the Site's east wing had been demolished months prior when logs confirmed otherwise). Some notes contained instructions that, when followed, prevented minor anomalies or revealed new containment threats; others led to false alarms and required resource allocation for non-events. Investigation: Initial investigation focused on conventional means of message delivery, intra-site pranks, and forgery. CCTV footage surrounding Dr. Rowan's immediate quarters and office showed no person delivering notes at the times Dr. Rowan reported. Physical forensics on paper and ink returned standard manufacturing IDs linking the paper to the site's office supplies depot. Mobile Task Force assignments devoted to breach prediction were consulted; no known entity with temporal messaging capabilities was present in containment at the time of emergence. Given the temporal content and Dr. Rowan's access to restricted chrono-manipulation records, research considered two primary hypotheses: Hypothesis A — Temporal Anomaly: SCP-████-notes were authored by Dr. Rowan's future self and transmitted backward along a yet-undefined temporal vector. Supporting evidence included the accurate prediction of two minor containment events (see Incident Reports 20██-A and 20██-C). The manner of delivery aligns with documented, anomalous retrocausal information flows (cf. Incident SCP- Temporal-██). If true, SCP-████ represents a low-energy, high-specificity retrochronal link localized to Dr. Rowan. Hypothesis B — Psychological/Memetic Manipulation by Contained Entity: A contained entity (see Containment Candidate Index) may have been manipulating Dr. Rowan's perception, implanting notes, or influencing him to create notes that would alter containment outcomes. Supporting evidence included occasional contradictions to known reality consistent with memetic misdirection and Dr. Rowan's increasing dissociation, which could be induced by exposure to memetic agents (cf. SCP-███-class memetics). No direct memetic signature was detected on the notes, though detection limits remain inconclusive. To adjudicate, the Foundation initiated a controlled protocol: - All writing implements were removed from Dr. Rowan's possession. He was placed under observation with two-way mirrors and continuous recording. Periodic memory tests were administered. A decoy memo pad containing inert memetic ink was left accessible. - The decoy remained untouched for 72 hours. The first post-restriction note (SCP-████-21) appeared inside Dr. Rowan's locked personal drawer. SCP-████-21 [Begin] Eli, They will think the camera will catch them. Cameras do not look up. The pad was a trick; the trick keeps. The drawer will keep you whole until you do the math wrong. We do not fix answers. —E. [End] The emergence of SCP-████-21 while under direct observation suggested either a breach in surveillance or a phenomenon not dependent on physical transmission. Additionally, video archives showed normal footage of the drawer and room with no anomaly; the footage itself later exhibited isolated frames of static in which Dr. Rowan's reflected image moved independently. Further testing involved isolating Dr. Rowan in a Faraday-memetic cell, providing only synthetic paper that mimicked Foundation memo paper. After 48 hours, no notes appeared. However, when a paper sample matching Foundation memo specifications (sourced from the offices) was placed in the cell, a note manifested on it within three hours. This implies a strong correlation between the original stationery's manufacturing lot and SCP-████ effects. Containment Outcome and Dr. Rowan: Dr. Rowan's trust in his own perception degraded throughout the observation period. He began performing actions explicitly to test whether he was following an instruction from the notes or from his own volition (e.g., counting door hinges aloud before entering a room; refusing to carry out simple directives). He reported auditory hallucinations of his voice telling him to "tell her about the child." He was replaced on active temporal recalibration duties and reassigned to a supervised analysis-only role. On 06/21/20██, a partial containment breach occurred in Lab East (Containment Event 20██-E). The breach involved a Class-3 cognitive mimic (designated SCP-███) that exploited temporal dissonance and auditory suggestion to escape. The breach was contained within four hours by combined temporal dampeners and MTF intervention. Post-event analysis found that several SCP-████-notes had warned of a breach on or around this date but contained contradictory instructions (e.g., "give her the stopwatch" vs. "do not perform the recalibration on 06/21"). Dr. Rowan followed a margin note he had assumed belonged to the future-self; this action inadvertently aligned with SCP-███'s exploit path. Whether this was coincidence, manipulation by SCP-███, or an unavoidable temporal loop remains unresolved. Conclusion: SCP-████ remains unclassified between temporal anomaly and memetic manipulation. The correlation between Foundation memo paper lot and effects suggests a memetic carrier embedded at manufacture or an unknown interaction with Foundation materials. Dr. Rowan's condition constitutes an ongoing risk: his future-directed notes can prevent or provoke breaches depending on interpretation. For safety, Dr. Rowan is to be kept from decision-making roles involving active containment; all future SCP-████-instances are to be quarantined and analyzed for signs of implanted directives. Final entry — Dr. Elias Rowan (excerpt from interview transcript prior to reassignment): "I used to trust my handwriting... I could tell which of my notes were drafts, which were firm. When the first one came I thought someone was testing me. Then the notes started telling me not to test. The last time I found a note it told me I wouldn't find it. I read that line three times before I realized I had read it before. I don't know if I'm saving them or being saved from them. Sometimes I think I put them there so I'd have someone to argue with later. Sometimes I think the someone is me and the arguing never ends." Interspersed Note (found inside interview transcript binder) [Begin] Eli, If you are reading this at the desk, close the folder and sleep now. If it's under your pillow, wake the alarm at 03:17 and do not look at the window. If you fold this twice they will know you counted. If you burn it, the smoke will remember you were brave. —E. [End]
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP report effectively captures the essence of the Foundation's clinical documentation style while weaving in a compelling narrative about temporal anomalies and psychological deterioration. The piece is structured as a formal SCP document with containment procedures, description, and addenda, which demonstrates strong adherence to the SCP format. The response excels at creating an atmosphere of mounting dread and confusion through the increasingly incoherent notes. The progression from relatively straightforward warnings to fragmented, reality-bending messages effectively conveys the deterioration of either the timeline, Dr. Rowan's mental state, or both. The notes themselves are particularly strong, with cryptic yet evocative language that suggests terrible consequences without explicitly stating them. The character of Dr. Rowan is developed primarily through the notes and his final interview excerpt, which effectively shows his psychological decline. His struggle with trusting his own perception comes through clearly, especially in lines like "I used to trust my handwriting..." The piece maintains a consistent clinical tone in the documentation sections while allowing for more personal expression in the notes and interview excerpt. However, the piece could benefit from more vivid descriptions of Dr. Rowan's day-to-day experiences with the notes. While we get glimpses of his deteriorating mental state, more first-person narrative sections showing his immediate reactions to finding notes would strengthen the emotional impact. The response leans heavily on telling us about his psychological state rather than showing it through his actions and thoughts. The narrative also occasionally becomes overly complex with references to various containment events and SCP entities that aren't fully explained, which can make it difficult to follow the exact sequence of events. Some of the technical jargon, while appropriate for an SCP document, occasionally obscures rather than clarifies the underlying story. Despite these issues, the piece successfully creates an unsettling atmosphere of temporal confusion and psychological horror. The ambiguous ending leaves the reader questioning whether Dr. Rowan is caught in a time loop, being manipulated by an entity, or experiencing some combination of both. This ambiguity is effective for the SCP format, which often leaves room for multiple interpretations. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 91.9
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-████ Object Class: Keter Special Containment Procedures: All discovered instances of SCP-████ (hereafter "doors") are to be contained on-site by Mobile Task Force Nu-9 ("Locksmiths") with support from local Foundation assets. Each door is to be isolated within a 50 m exclusion zone and monitored via stationary and remote reconnaissance. Personnel approaching within 10 m are to be micro-tagged and undergo immediate debrief and memetic screening. No door is to be opened without written authorization from at least two (2) O5 Council members. Where openings have already occurred, Foundation teams will secure ingress/egress and attempt to map and inventory any connected spaces. In every case where subject-matter removal by external agents (designated SCP-████-B) is observed, Foundation units are to attempt non-confrontational observation, recording, and, if feasible, tagging of removed items. Direct engagement with SCP-████-B is restricted to D-class and remotely operated units except by express order of O5-█ in the event of exigent threat. All files discovered within SCP-████-A (the inner archive) are to be copied, cross-referenced against Foundation databases, and quarantined. Under no circumstances will Foundation archival staff assume unique provenance claims in recovered documents without consensus review. Personnel found to appear in archival personnel files dated pre-Foundation are to be placed under continuous surveillance. Description: SCP-████ manifests as unremarkable, unmarked doorways that appear within abandoned or derelict structures across all surveyed continents. Doors are standard wooden-panel designs varying between single and double-leaf; each instance exhibits an identical pattern of shallow scratches concentric to the doorknob on the pull side (see Addendum 1). Scratches do not penetrate to underlayers and resist analysis for tool or biological residue. Opening an SCP-████ door (SCP-████-A) does not reveal the space contained within the hosting structure. In every documented opening, stakeholders encounter an expansive interior that defies the external building footprint and conventional Euclidean geometry: vaulted archives, long corridors disappearing into darkness, and rooms stacked in non-Euclidean arrangements. Interior volume scales to accommodate perceived need; teams have walked for hours without reaching opposing structural boundaries. Environmental readings inside SCP-████-A are anomalously stable: constant low humidity, marginally cool temperatures (15–18°C), and no detectable microbial life beyond inert dust. Contents are overwhelmingly archival: bound volumes, ledgers, microfilm, crystalline tablets, and automated retrieval stacks beyond contemporary technology. Many documents reference a preternatural global civilization (hereafter "Prior World") destroyed by what is referred to repeatedly as "the Containment Failure." The Prior World's chronology is inconsistent with established human history and includes references to cities, governance structures, and technologies the Foundation has not previously cataloged. Of particular concern are repeated direct references to entities matching Foundation descriptors under alternate nomenclature (examples: "Custodial Circle," "First Keepers"). Multiple personnel dossiers within SCP-████-A contain names, photographs, and service records that correspond exactly to present Foundation staff, dated between 220–500 years prior to their lives as recorded in Foundation files. These files frequently list additional past assignments and commendations that contradict known Foundation history. Exploration Log Excerpt SCP-████-E9 (Team Lead: Agent Ortiz) T+00:00 — Entry through SCP-████ instance located in the basement of a condemned textile mill, ████, Spain. Scratches present. Per protocol, electronic seals deployed. Team proceeds as pair, tethered. T+00:12 — Corridor opens into three-aisled hall. Stacks extend leftward; signage in unknown script (see recovered plate R-17). Ambient humidity 16%. No microfauna. T+02:03 — Discovered catalog room labelled "Registry: Containments—Temporal." Retrieval system active. Numerous ledgers bearing Foundation iconography (cross-checked against internal archives show no match). T+03:45 — Found personnel file labeled "Ariela Ortiz — Custodial Circle #4." Photograph matches Agent Ortiz (ID ████). File lists active service in "Containment Archive 3" dated 312 YW (Year of the Wane). Entry lists further assignment: "Observation of Removals — Omega Teams." T+04:22 — Audible operation detected ahead. From corridor: three figures in gray suits with opaque helmets and NIOSH-style respirators actively loading crates onto a wheeled rack. Markings on suits: circular patch with three concentric rings and the word "REMOVAL" in antiform glyphs. Personnel appear non-hostile; when Team attempts to approach, figures freeze, raise palms, then retreat through a side door that does not correspond with Team map. Door closes behind them; mechanical drive engages and vanishes. T+04:26 — Team proceeds to the side door. Door leads to storage bay now empty. Tracks on floor (compressed dust) indicate recent movement of heavy crates. No biological residue. Remote cameras later revealed the "REMOVAL" personnel did not return to the main corridor. T+04:50 — Found dossier containing names of several ███ Foundation personnel, including "Councilor [redacted]" and "O5-██." Footnote on dossier: "Unauthorized visitation noted — records sealed." Entry timestamped 419 YW. End log. Recovered Document Excerpts (translated, redactions preserved where present) — Excerpt from Ledger "Known Keepers and Affiliations," page 142: "…the Keepers of the Circle now bear many names across ages. In the Northern Vault they called themselves the Foundation for the Preservation of Limits. In the years preceding the Failure, such orders were subdivided into Custodial Circles; the Fifth Circle accepted external observers from the Keep: the Council of Eight. Names recorded in private rolls include those later known as [O5-██], [O5-██], and an individual named 'Dr. Victor Halsey' who is later listed as 'missing' following the Burnings." — Notation from "After-Action: Containment Failure" (fragmentary): "…we attempted to quarantine the Anomalous Archive nodes. Protocols failed when corridors looped back upon themselves and retrieval shadows—agents for the Archive—began removing holdings. The Council mandated closure, but two Councillors entered the stacks alone. Transmission log shows their access time; they did not return. Subsequent entries crossed out." — Personnel File (photograph confirmed to be Agent S. Weiss) "Name: S. Weiss Service: Custodian — Retrieval & Inventory Date of Birth: 19██ Assigned: Archive Sector VII, Chronology Wing Service Period: 302–326 YW Comments: Reassigned following Containment Incident 326. Personally responsible for re-shelving 'Class-7 Errata' under directive Auth-Prime." Notes: - The "YW" dating system appears internally consistent throughout SCP-████-A materials but cannot be correlated to any known calendar with absolute certainty. Radiocarbon analysis of paper substrates yields ages inconsistent with the YW dates yet shows centuries-old cellulose degradation patterns. - Images of present staff within archival dossiers are physically accurate and show aging inconsistent with subject. Psychological evaluations of staff who find their own images within SCP-████-A show varying degrees of dissociation and insistence on prior service. SCP-████-B — Retrieval Entities: Repeatedly observed within SCP-████-A are groups resembling civilian hazardous-materials teams (designation SCP-████-B). Their suits conform to no known manufacture; their movements are systematically efficient and non-aggressive when unengaged. When approached, SCP-████-B abandon material in situ and withdraw by previously unobserved egresses. Attempts to follow have failed; egress paths loop or terminate at inaccessible voids. When intercepted, SCP-████-B have emitted a high-frequency signal causing nausea and disorientation; after such events, affected personnel report fragmented memories of walking without sight and encountering "doors with scratches." Addendum 1 — Scratches: Microscopic analysis of the scratches around each SCP-████ doorknob shows ordered abrasion consistent with gloved repeated contact. Under polarized light, residues within grooves reveal trace organics which match no known human skin profile. Attempts to replicate mark patterns via tools or simulated wear have failed. Addendum 2 — Unauthorized O5 Visitation: During a 20██‡ unauthorized sweep of SCP-████-A (breach recorded by covert camera feed), footage captured two individuals later identified as members of the O5 Council entering an otherwise sealed stack. Camera time stamps correspond to ledger notations found within SCP-████-A describing "Council Inspections." No authorized record of such inspections exists in Foundation logs. The footage ceases abruptly; recovery teams found a floor tile with faint shoe impressions matching an O5 seal and a scrap of an O5 robe thread. Investigation into possible temporal or memetic contamination is ongoing. O5 members in question have denied knowledge beyond classified need-to-know. Closing Statement: SCP-████ poses a complex ontological threat. It is simultaneously a repository of otherwise impossible histories and an active actor in the preservation and removal of those histories via SCP-████-B. The presence of Foundation personnel in its records—dating centuries before their biological existence—and evidence that leadership has engaged with the Archive without institutional authorization imply either gaps in Foundation history, temporal entanglements, or an archive that records not only the past but possible pasts. Containment must proceed with caution. The Archive appears to be selective in what it retains and what it permits to be excised; understanding its selection criteria is Priority One. Footnote: All personnel who have seen dossiers containing their own images are to receive memetic counseling and be scheduled for review within the next 72 hours. Any instance of SCP-████ found outside derelict buildings (e.g., within inhabited spaces) is to be reported immediately and cordoned.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates exceptional adherence to the SCP Foundation format and style. The author has created a compelling anomaly that perfectly fits the prompt requirements: unmarked doors in abandoned buildings leading to an impossible archive with references to a previous civilization and unauthorized O5 Council involvement. The piece excels in world-building through meticulous attention to detail. The containment procedures are appropriately technical and thorough. The description of SCP-████ is methodical, gradually revealing the anomaly's nature while maintaining an air of mystery. The exploration log effectively conveys the team's discovery process and introduces the hazmat-like entities (SCP-████-B) who flee when approached, exactly as requested. The writing maintains the clinical, detached tone characteristic of SCP entries while still conveying the unsettling implications of the anomaly. The author skillfully incorporates document excerpts that hint at a deeper conspiracy and temporal anomalies. The references to Foundation personnel appearing in centuries-old records create an effective sense of unease and ontological uncertainty. Particularly strong is how the author handles the O5 Council unauthorized visits. Rather than making this a central plot point that overwhelms the entry, it's presented as one disturbing element among many, maintaining the mystery while fulfilling the prompt requirement. The prose is precise and economical, avoiding unnecessary flourishes while still creating vivid imagery of the impossible archive spaces. The exploration log effectively uses timestamps and technical language to create authenticity. If there are weaknesses, they might include some repetition in how the anomaly's implications are described, and perhaps the entry could have delved deeper into the psychological effects on personnel who discover their own images in the archive. Additionally, while the "YW" dating system is intriguing, it remains somewhat underdeveloped. Overall, this is an exemplary SCP entry that balances technical writing with creative world-building, maintains the appropriate tone throughout, and fulfills all the prompt requirements while creating a genuinely intriguing and unsettling anomaly. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
